revision.comment: /* In popular culture */ removed half of a sentence
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Wiktionary|feck|feckless}} '''''Feck''''' (or, in some senses, '''''fek''''' or '''''feic''''') has several [[vernacular]] meanings and variations in [[Hiberno-English]], [[Scots language|Scots]] and [[Middle English]].
==Modern English== * Slang [[Profanity|expletive]] employed as an attenuated alternative ([[minced oath]]) to ''[[fuck]]'' to express disbelief, pain, anger, or contempt in a given situation. However, it does not mean to have sex with in the same way that fuck does, and those aware of this use consider it a lesser expletive than fuck.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/feck?q=feck |title=feck - definition of feck in English from the Oxford dictionary |publisher=Oxforddictionaries.com |date= |accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref> * [[Verb]] meaning 'to steal' (e.g., 'They had fecked cash out of the rector's room.'<ref>[[A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man|''Portrait of the Artist'']], [[James Joyce]], (1964) p. 40</ref>)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0voNAAAAQAAJ&lpg=PA310&dq=feck%20slang&lr=&pg=PA310#v=onepage&q=&f=false |title=The Routledge Dictionary of Historical Slang - Eric Partridge |publisher=Books.google.ie |date= |accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref> * [[Verb]] meaning in Irish slang 'to throw' (e.g., 'He's got no manners at all. I asked him nicely for the remote control, and he fecked it across the table at me.')
==Scots and Late Middle English== '''''Feck''''' (or '''''fek''''' or '''''feic''''') is a form of ''effeck'', which is in turn the Scots cognate of the modern English word [[wikt:en:Effect|effect]]. However, this Scots noun has additional significance: # Efficacy; force; value; [[Return on investment|return]] # Amount; quantity (or a large amount/quantity) # The greater or larger part (when used with a [[Article (grammar)|definite article]])
From the first sense we derive ''[[wikt:feckless|feckless]]'', meaning witless, weak or ineffective; worthless; irresponsible; indifferent; lazy. ''Feckless'' remains a part of the [[Modern English]] and [[Scottish English]] [[lexicon]]s; it appears in a number of Scottish [[adage]]s:
:"Feckless folk are aye fain o ane anither."
:"Feckless fools should keep canny tongues."
In his 1881 short story ''[[Thrawn Janet]]'', [[Robert Louis Stevenson]] invokes the second sense of ''feck'' as cited above:
:"He had a feck o' books wi' him—mair than had ever been seen before in a' that presbytery..."
[[Robert Burns]] uses the third sense of ''feck'' in the final [[stanza]] of his 1792 poem "Kellyburn Braes":
:I hae been a Devil the feck o' my life, :Hey, and the rue grows bonie wi' thyme; :"But ne'er was in hell till I met wi' a wife," :And the thyme it is wither'd, and rue is in prime
==Debate about the word's level of offensiveness== [[Magners|Magners Irish Cider]] have received complaints relating to an advert in which a man tells bees to "feck off": members of the public were concerned that young children could be badly influenced by seeing this advert. [[Magners]] claimed that the "feck off" mention in the advert was a "mild rebuff" to the bees, rather than an [[Profanity|expletive]]. The [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority (ASA)]] has ruled that the poster is suitable for display.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.scotsman.com/latestnews/What-the-feck-Ad-gets.4777178.jp |title=What the feck! Ad gets the all-clear - The Scotsman |publisher=News.scotsman.com |date= |accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref>
In a 1998 interview on [[Nickelodeon (UK and Ireland)|Nickelodeon]], Irish girl group ''[[B*Witched]]'' landed in hot water when a viewer made a complaint alleging that one of the teenagers had used the phrase "fuck off". Although Nickelodeon maintained that the singer had in fact said "feck off", which they described "a phrase made popular by the Channel 4 sitcom ''[[Father Ted]]''," the item was found to be in breach of the ITC Programme Code and the complaint was thus upheld.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ofcom.org.uk/static/archive/itc/itc_publications/complaints_reports/programme_complaints/show_complaint.asp-prog_complaint_id=78.html |title=Programme Complaints & Interventions Report |publisher=Ofcom.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref>
==In popular culture== The [[Channel 4]] situation comedy ''[[Father Ted]]'' helped to export and popularise this use of ''feck'' through its [[Fictional character|characters]]' liberal use of the word, especially by the drunk priest [[Father Jack Hackett|Father Jack]]. {{Citation needed|date=April 2015}}
In 2004 [[FCUK|French Connection UK]], sellers of the popular "FCUK" [[T-shirt]], won a legal injunction in [[Dublin]] that barred a local business from printing and selling a T-shirt marked "FCEK The Irish Connection".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090502173838/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/article393415.ece] </ref>
==See also== {{Wiktionary|feck}} {{Wiktionary|feckless}} * [[Minced oath]] * [[Cognate]] * [[False cognate]] * [[Hiberno-English#Turns of phrase|Hiberno-English – Turns of phrase]] * [[Profanity]] * [[Vulgarism]] * [[PHECC]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== * Walker, Colin S. K. ''Scottish Proverbs''. [[Edinburgh]]: Birlinn Limited, 1996. {{ISBN|1-874744-30-0}} * ''Webster's College Dictionary''. New York City: [[Random House]], 1996. {{ISBN|0-679-43886-6}} * ''Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary''. [[Springfield, Massachusetts]]: [[Merriam Webster|G. & C. Merriam Company Co.]], 1913. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071205102451/http://www.irishslang.net/ Irish Slang] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050521001903/http://www.englishirishdictionary.com/ Irish Dictionary Online]
[[Category:Father Ted]] [[Category:Profanity]] [[Category:Scots language]] [[Category:Scottish English]] [[Category:Interjections]] [[Category:Irish slang]]

revision.comment: /* Gender-specific words */
revision.text:
{{Grammar series}} A system of [[grammatical gender]], whereby every [[noun]] was treated as either masculine, feminine or neuter, existed in [[Old English]], but fell out of use during the [[Middle English]] period. [[Modern English]] retains features relating to [[natural gender]], namely the use of certain nouns and [[pronoun]]s (such as ''he'' and ''she'') to refer specifically to persons or animals of one or other genders and certain others (such as ''it'') for sexless objects – although [[#Personal pronouns|feminine pronouns]] are sometimes used when referring to ships (and more uncommonly some airplanes and analogous machinery) and nation states. Some aspects of gender usage in English have been influenced by the movement towards a preference for [[gender-neutral language]]. This applies in particular to avoidance of the default use of the masculine ''he'' when referring to a person of unknown gender, usually using the neuter ''they'' as a third-person singular, and avoidance of the use of certain feminine forms of nouns (such as ''authoress'' and ''poetess''). Increasingly, the "male" form of such nouns is used for both men and women.Stevenson, Angus (ed.) (2010). ''Oxford Dictionary of English'', 3rd Ed., Oxford University Press, Oxford, New York, p. 598. {{ISBN|978-0-19-957112-3}}. ==Gender in Old English== [[Old English]] had a system of grammatical gender similar to that of modern [[German language|German]], with three genders: masculine, feminine, neuter. [[determiner (class)|Determiner]]s and [[attributive adjective]]s showed gender inflection in [[agreement (linguistics)|agreement]] with the noun they modified. Also the nouns themselves followed different declension patterns depending on their gender. Moreover, the third-person [[personal pronouns]], as well as [[interrogative word|interrogative]] and [[relative pronoun]]s, were chosen according to the grammatical gender of their [[antecedent (grammar)|antecedent]]. Old English grammatical gender was, as in other [[Germanic languages]], remarkably opaque, that is, one often could not know the gender of a noun by its meaning or by the form of the word; this was especially true for nouns referencing inanimate objects. Learners would have had to simply memorize which word goes with which gender.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/16404179|title=Grammatical gender in English, 950 to 1250|last=1939-|first=Jones, Charles,|date=1988|publisher=Croom Helm|isbn=0709914768|location=London|oclc=16404179}}{{rp|10}} Though nouns referring to human males were generally masculine and for the most part the masculine went with human males and the feminine went with human females, as Charles Jones noted, "it is with those nouns which show explicit female reference that the sex specifying function of the gender classification system appears to break down,..." Most words referencing human females were feminine, but there was a sizable number of words that were either neuter or even masculine.{{rp|6-7}} Here are the discrepant nouns referring specifically to human females as listed by Jones:{{rp|7}} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !Noun !! Gender !! Meaning !! Modern cognates |- !æwe | '''neut.''' || "married woman" || |- !broþorwif | '''neut.''' || "brother's wife" || |- !fæmenhadesmon | '''masc.''' || (of a woman) "virgin" || |- !foligerwif | '''neut.''' || "prostitute" || |- !forþwif | '''neut.''' || "matron" || |- !freowif | '''neut.''' || "freewoman" || |- !hiredwifmon | '''masc.''' || "female member of a household" || |- !lærningmægden | '''neut.''' || "female pupil" || |- !mædencild | '''neut.''' || "female child" || |- !mægden | '''neut.''' || "young girl" || English ''maid'', ''maiden'';
German ''das Mädchen'' |- !mægdenman | '''masc.''' || (of a woman) "virgin" || |- !mægþman | '''masc.''' || (of a woman) "virgin" || |- !mennenu | '''neut.''' || "handmaiden" || |- !næmenwif | '''neut.''' || "married woman" || |- !sigewif | '''neut.''' || "victorious woman" || |- !siþwif | '''neut.''' || "noble lady" || |- !unrihtwif | '''neut.''' || "mistress" || |- !wif | '''neut.''' || "woman" || English ''wife'';
German ''das Weib'' |- !wifcild | '''neut.''' || "female child" || |- !wiffreond | '''masc.''' || "female friend" || |- !wifhand | '''masc.''' || "heiress" || |- !wifmann | '''masc.''' || "woman" || English ''woman'' |- !wynmæg | '''neut.''' || "winsome maid" || |- !yrfenuma | '''neut.''' || "female heir" || |- |} Old English had multiple generic nouns for "woman" stretching across all 3 genders: for example, in addition to the neuter ''wif'' and the masculine ''wifmann'' listed above, there was also the feminine ''frowe''.{{rp|6}} For the gender-neutral nouns for "child", there was the feminine ''byren'' in addition to the neuter ''bearn'' and the neuter ''cild'' (compare English ''child''). And even with nouns referring to persons, one could not always determine gender by meaning or form: for example, with 2 words ending in ''-mæg'', there was the female-specific '''neuter''' noun ''wynmæg'', meaning "winsome maid" or attractive woman; as well as the gender-neutral noun meaning "paternal kindred" or member of father's side of the family, but which was grammatically '''feminine''': ''fædernmæg''.{{rp|7-8}} For details of the declension patterns and pronoun systems, see [[Old English grammar]]. ==Decline of grammatical gender== By the 11th century, the role of grammatical gender in Old English was beginning to decline.{{Harvnb|Curzan|2003|pp=84, 86}}: "[T]he major gender shift for inanimate nouns in written texts occurs in late Old English/early Middle English, but {{Nowrap|[...]}} the seeds of change are already present in Old English before 1000 AD." The [[Middle English]] of the 13th century was in transition to the loss of a gender system.{{Harvnb|Curzan|2003|p=86}}: "[G]rammatical gender remained healthy in the personal pronouns through late Old English; it is not until early Middle English that the balance of gender concord in the pronouns tips towards natural gender, at least in the written language." One element of this process was the change in the functions of the words ''the'' and ''that'' (then spelt ''þe'' and ''þat''; see also [[Old English determiners]]): previously these had been non-neuter and neuter forms respectively of a single [[determiner]], but in this period ''the'' came to be used generally as a definite article and ''that'' as a [[demonstrative]]; both thus ceased to manifest any gender differentiation.{{cite book|last=Shinkawa|first=Seiji|title=Unhistorical Gender Assignment in Laʒamon's Brut|year=2012|publisher=Peter Lang|location=Switzerland}} The loss of gender classes was part of a general decay of [[Inflection#Examples in English|inflectional endings]] and [[Old English declension|declensional classes]] by the end of the 14th century. While inflectional reduction seems to have been incipient in the English language itself, some theories suggest that it was accelerated by contact with Old Norse, especially in midland and northern dialects.{{Harvnb|Curzan|2003|p=53}}. Gender loss began in the north of England; the south-east and the south-west Midlands were the most linguistically conservative regions, and Kent retained traces of gender in the 1340s.{{cite book|last=Lass|first=Roger|editor=Richard M. Hogg, David Denison|title=A history of the English language|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U5FDi8WksqYC&pg=PA70|year=2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-66227-3|page=70|chapter=Phonology and morphology}} [[Middle English#Chancery Standard|Late 14th-century London English]] had almost completed the shift away from grammatical gender, and Modern English retains no [[morphology (linguistics)|morphological]] agreement of words with grammatical gender.{{cite book|last1=Hellinger|first1=Marlis|last2=Bussmann|first2=Hadumod|title=Gender across languages: the linguistic representation of women and men|chapter=English — Gender in a global language|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aBMX57viyRwC&pg=PA107|volume=1|year=2001|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|isbn=90-272-1841-2|page=107}} ==Modern English== Gender is no longer an inflectional category in [[Modern English]].Rodney Huddleston and Geoffrey K. Pullum, ''[[The Cambridge Grammar of the English Language]]'' (2002). The only traces of the Old English gender system are found in the system of pronoun–antecedent [[agreement (linguistics)|agreement]], although this is now based on natural gender [http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761564210_2/English_Language.html 'English Language',] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5kwpdH4jo?url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761564210_2/English_Language.html |date=2009-11-01 }} ''Encarta'', (Microsoft Corporation, 2007). "The distinctions of grammatical gender in English were replaced by those of natural gender.". 2009-10-31. – the [[sex]], gender identity, or perceived sexual characteristics, of the pronoun's [[reference|referent]]. Another manifestation of natural gender that continues to function in English is the use of certain nouns to refer specifically to persons or animals of a particular sex: ''widow/widower'', ''actor/actress'', etc. [[Benjamin Whorf]] described grammatical gender in English as a [[Covert (linguistics)|covert]] grammatical category.Benjamin Lee Whorf, 'Grammatical Categories', ''Language'' 21 (1945): 1–11. See also Robert A. Hall Jr, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/453074 'Sex Reference and Grammatical Gender in English'], ''American Speech'' 26 (1951): 170–172. He noted that gender as a property inherent in nouns (rather than in their referents) is not entirely absent from modern English: different pronouns may be appropriate for the same referent depending on what noun has been used.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} ===Personal pronouns=== The third-person singular [[English personal pronouns|personal pronouns]] are chosen according to the natural gender of their [[antecedent (grammar)|antecedent]] or [[reference|referent]]. As a general rule: *''[[he]]'' (and its related forms ''him'', ''himself'', ''his'') is used when the referent is male, or something to which male characteristics are attributed; *''[[she]]'' (and ''her'', ''herself'', ''hers'') is used when the referent is female, or something to which female characteristics are attributed – this is common especially with vessels such as [[ship]]s and airplanes, and sometimes with countries. An example is in ''[[God Bless America]]'': "Stand beside her, and guide her through the night with a light from above." *''[[it (pronoun)|it]]'' (and ''itself'', ''its'') is used when the referent is something inanimate or intangible, a non-animal life-form such as a plant, an animal of unknown sex, or, less often, a child when the sex is unspecified or deemed unimportant.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} ''It'' is also used in the interrogative for people in some phrases such as, "Who is it?". Pronoun agreement is often with the natural gender of the referent (the person or thing denoted) rather than simply the antecedent (a noun or [[noun phrase]] which the pronoun replaces). For example, one might say either ''the doctor and his patients'' or ''the doctor and her patients'', depending on one's knowledge or assumptions about the sex of the doctor in question, as the phrase ''the doctor'' (the antecedent) does not itself have any specific natural gender. Also, pronouns are sometimes used without any explicit antecedent. However, as noted above (the example with ''child'' and ''daughter''), the choice of pronoun may also be affected by the particular noun used in the antecedent. (When the antecedent is a collective noun, such as ''family'' or ''team'', and the pronoun refers to the members of the group denoted rather than the group as a single entity, a [[plural]] pronoun may be chosen: compare ''the family and its origins''; ''the family and their breakfast-time arguments''. See also [[synesis]].) Because there is no third-person singular gender-neutral pronoun for animate referents, problems arise when the referent is a person of unknown or unspecified sex. Traditionally the male forms ''he'' etc. or the singular ''they'' have been used in such situations, but in contemporary English (partly because of the movement towards gender-neutral language) the male forms are often avoided in this context, although they are still considered proper.{{cite book |last1=Bernstein |first1=Theodore |title=The Careful Writer |date=1977 |publisher=Atheneum |location=New York |isbn=0689705557 |page=351}} Possible alternatives include: *use of ''he or she'', ''he/she'', ''s/he'', etc. *alternation or random mixture of use of ''she'' and ''he'' *use of [[singular they|singular ''they'']] (common especially in informal language) *use of ''it'' (normally only considered when the referent is a young child) Although the use of ''she'' and ''he'' for inanimate objects is not very frequent in Standard Modern English, it is in fact fairly widespread in some varieties of English. Gender assignment to inanimate nouns in these dialects is sometimes fairly systematic. For example, in some dialects of southwest England, masculine pronouns are used for individuated or countable matter, such as iron tools, while the neuter form is used for non-individuated matter, such as liquids, fire and other substances.Compare the similar Early Modern English formation which is typified in the prose of the [[King James Bible]] (or [[Authorized Version]]), here shewed in the Gospel of St Matthew, v,13: Ye are the salt of the earth: but if the salt have lost '''his''' savour, wherewith shall it be salted? it is thenceforth good for nothing, but to be cast out, and to be trodden under foot of men. ====Animals==== In principle, animals are triple-gender nouns, being able to take masculine, feminine and neuter pronouns. However, animals viewed as less important to humans, also known as ‘lower animals’, are generally referred to using ''it''; higher (domestic) animals may more often be referred to using ''he'' and ''she'', when their sex is known.{{cite book |last=Siemund |first=Peter |title=Pronominal Gender in English: A Study of English Varieties form a Cross-Linguistic Perspective |year=2008 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York}} If the sex of the animal is not known, the masculine pronoun is often used with a sex-neutral meaning. For example, ''Person A: Ah there’s an ant'' ''Person B: Well put '''him''' outside'' Animate pronouns ''he'' and ''she'' are usually applied to animals when personification and/or individuation occurs. Personification occurs whenever human attributes are applied to the noun. For example: ''A widow bird sat mourning for '''her''' love.'' Specifically named animals are an example of individuation, such as ''Peter Rabbit'' or ''Blob the Whale''. In these instances, it is more likely that animate pronouns ''he'' or ''she'' will be used to represent them. These rules also apply to other triple-gender nouns, including ideas, inanimate objects, and words like ''infant'' and ''child''. ====Ships==== Traditionally, oceans, [[countries]], and [[ship]]s, even those named after men such as [[DDG-52|USS ''Barry'']], have been referred to using the feminine pronouns. This usage is currently in decline (though still more common for ships, particularly in nautical usage, than for countries); in [[American English]] it is advised against by ''[[The Chicago Manual of Style]]''.{{citation |mode=cs1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EBMlLYwqmjYC&q=%22it%20(rather%20than%20she%20or%20her)%20is%20generally%20preferred%22 |title=The Chicago Manual of Style |year=2003 |page=356 |editor-last=Grossman |editor-first=John |publisher=University of Chicago Press |edition=15th |isbn=978-0-226-10403-4 |lccn=2003001860 |oclc=51553085 |ol=15979229W |quote=When a pronoun is used to refer to a vessel, the neuter ''it'' (rather than ''she'' or ''her'') is generally preferred.}} ====Transgender persons==== Some [[genderqueer]] or similarly-identified people prefer not to use either ''he'' or ''she'', but a different pronoun such as [[singular they|they]], ''zie'', or so forth.{{cite news |last1= Binkley |first1= Collin |title= Pick your own pronoun at university. |url= http://www.pressreader.com/canada/toronto-star/20150919/281913066905634 |accessdate=24 April 2016 |work=Toronto Star |agency= Associated Press |publisher= Toronto Star |date=19 September 2015 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170218010206/http://www.pressreader.com/canada/toronto-star/20150919/281913066905634 |archivedate=2017-02-18}} ===Other pronouns=== Other English pronouns are not subject to male/female distinctions, although in some cases a distinction between [[animacy|animate]] and inanimate referents is made. For example, the word ''[[who (pronoun)|who]]'' (as an [[interrogative word|interrogative]] or [[relative pronoun]]) refers to a person or people, and rarely to animals (although the possessive form ''whose'' can be used as a relative pronoun even when the antecedent is inanimate), while ''which'' and ''what'' refer to inanimate things (and non-human animals). Since these pronouns function on a binary gender system, distinguishing only between animate and inanimate entities, this suggests that English has a second gender system which contrasts with the primary gender system. It should also be noted that relative and interrogative pronouns do not encode number. This is shown in the following example: ''The man '''who''' lost his head ''vs.'' the men '''who''' lost their heads'' Other pronouns which show a similar distinction include ''everyone/everybody'' vs. ''everything'', ''no one/nobody'' vs. ''nothing'', etc. ===Gender-specific words=== Many words in modern English refer specifically to people or animals of a particular sex, although sometimes the specificity is being lost (for example, ''duck'' need not refer exclusively to a female bird; cf. [[Donald Duck]]).{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}} Likewise, many feminine and masculine job titles (steward/stewardess, waiter/waitress) have undergone a process of becoming gender-neutralised in recent decades (see below). An example of an English word that has retained gender-specific spellings is the noun-form of blond/blonde, with the former being masculine and the latter being feminine. ==Gender neutrality in English== {{main article|Gender neutrality in English}} {{refimprove section|date=May 2014}} Gender neutrality in English became a growing area of interest among academics during [[Second Wave Feminism]], when the work of [[structural linguistics|structuralist]] linguist [[Ferdinand de Saussure]], and his theories on [[semiotics]], became more well known in academic circles. By the 1960s and 1970s, [[post-structuralism|post-structuralist]] theorists, particularly in France, brought wider attention to gender-neutrality theory, and the concept of supporting gender equality through conscious changes to language. Feminists analyzing the English language put forward their own theories about the power of language to create and enforce gender determinism and the marginalization of the feminine. Debates touched on such issues as changing the term "stewardess" to the gender-neutral "flight attendant", "fireman" to "fire fighter", "mailman" to "mail carrier", and so on. At the root of this contentiousness may have been feminists' backlash{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} against the English language's shift from "grammatical gender" to "natural gender" during the early Modern era{{cite book|last=Meyer|first=Charles F.|title=Introducing English Linguistics International Student Edition|year=2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521152211|page=14}} coinciding with the spread of institutional prescriptive grammar rules in English schools. These theories have been challenged by some researchers, with attention given to additional possible social, ethnic, economic, and cultural influences on language and gender.{{Harvnb|Curzan|2003|pp=39, 151, 156}}. The impact on mainstream language has been limited,{{Harvnb|Cameron|1992|p=29}}. yet has led to lasting changes in practice. Features of gender-neutral language in English may include: *Avoidance of [[gender-specific job title]]s, or caution in their use;{{Cite news|url=https://www.elc.edu/english-grammar-lessons-gender-usage/|title=English Grammar Lessons - Gender Usage - ELC|date=2017-06-07|work=ELC - English Language Center|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}} *Avoidance of the use of ''man'' and ''mankind'' to refer to humans in general; *Avoidance of the use of ''he'', ''him'' and ''his'' when referring to a person of unspecified sex (see under {{slink||Personal pronouns}} above). Certain naming practices (such as the use of ''Mrs'' and ''Miss'' to distinguish married and unmarried women) may also be discouraged on similar grounds. For more details and examples, see [[Gender neutrality in English]]. ==See also== {{Wiktionary|gender}} * [[English grammar]] * [[Gender-neutral language]] * [[History of English]] ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== {{Refbegin}} *{{Cite book|title= Feminism and Linguistic Theory|last= Cameron|first= Deborah|publisher= [[Palgrave Macmillan]]|year= 1992|isbn= 978-0-312-08376-2|edition= 2nd|location= New York, NY|ref= harv}} *{{Cite book|title= Gender Shifts in the History of English|last= Curzan|first= Anne|publisher= [[Cambridge University Press]]|year= 2003|isbn= 978-0-521-82007-3|location= Cambridge|ref= harv}} {{Refend}} [[Category:Grammatical gender|English]] [[Category:English grammar]]

page.title: Glossary of Japanese words of Dutch origin

revision.comment: Undid revision 868751166 by [[Special:Contributions/60.241.57.6|60.241.57.6]] ([[User talk:60.241.57.6|talk]]) - rvt apparent vandalism
revision.text:
[[File:Dutch personnel and Japanese women watching an incoming towed Dutch sailing ship at Dejima by Kawahara Keiga.jpg|thumb|Painting by [[Kawahara Keiga]]: ''Arrival of a Dutch Ship''. [[Philipp Franz von Siebold]] at [[Dejima]] with his Japanese wife Kusumoto Otaki and their baby-daughter [[Kusumoto Ine]] observing a Dutch ship towed into Nagasaki harbour using a ''teresukoppu'' ([[telescope]]).]]
'''Japanese words of Dutch origin''' started to develop when the [[Dutch East India Company]] initiated trading in Japan from the [[factory (trading post)|factory]] of [[Hirado]] in 1609. In 1640, the Dutch were transferred to [[Dejima]], and from then on until 1854 remained the only Westerners allowed access to Japan, during Japan's ''"[[sakoku]]"'' seclusion period.
Numerous exchanges occurred, leading to a branch of Western learning in Japan known as ''[[rangaku]]'' (蘭学), or "Dutch learning" where the "ran" (蘭) in ''rangaku'' comes from "Oranda" the Japanese word for [[Holland]], and means Dutch while "gaku" (学) is of Sino-Japanese origin and means "Learning".<ref name="Loveday"/> In the process, a number of terms were adopted from Dutch into the Japanese language. At one point, some 3,000 words are thought to have been used, especially in the areas of technical and scientific vocabulary.<ref name="Loveday"/> About 160 such words of Dutch origin remain in use today in standard Japanese.<ref name="Loveday"/> {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" | |- ! Japanese transliteration (''[[rōmaji]]'') ! Japanese term (''kanji'' or ''kana'') ! Dutch term ! English term(s) ! Details |- |- |arukari <ref name="Sanseido">[http://daijirin.dual-d.net/extra/gairaigo.html Sanseido dual dictionary]</ref> |アルカリ |alkali |[[alkali]] |From Arabic, through Dutch. |- |arukōru <ref name="Loveday"/> |アルコール |alcohol |[[alcohol]] |From Arabic, through Dutch. |- |asubesuto <ref name="Sanseido"/> |アスベスト |asbest |[[asbestos]] |From Greek, through Dutch. |- |bīru <ref name="DutchConsulate">"[http://www.mfa.nl/tok-en/dutch-japanese Dutch-Japanese Relations]," ''[[Netherlands]] Consulate General at [[Osaka]]-[[Kobe]]''</ref> |ビール, 麦酒 |bier |[[beer]] | |- |bisuketto <ref name="Loveday"/> |ビスケット |beschuit |[[biscuit]] |Reinforcement of Portuguese ''biscoito''. |- |bōru <ref name="Loveday"/> |ボール |boor |[[drill]], bore |After 1720. |- |buriki <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ブリキ |blik |[[tin]] | |- |chifusu <ref name="Sanseido"/> |チフス |tyfus |[[typhus]] |From Greek, through Dutch. |- |chinki <ref name="Sanseido"/> |チンキ |tinctuur |[[tincture]] |Shortened from チンキテュール (''chinkityūru''). |- |dansu |ダンス |dans |dance | |- |doitsu |ドイツ |Duits |[[Germany]], [[German (disambiguation)|German]] | |- |dokku |ドック |dok |(dry) dock | |- |dontaku <ref name="Loveday"/> |ドンタク |zondag |[[Sunday]] |Also occasionally found as ゾンタク (''zontaku''). Appears from the early {{w|Meiji period}}, after 1868. |- |doronken <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ドロンケン |dronken |[[drunk]] | |- |ekisu <ref name="Sanseido"/> |エキス |extract |[[extract]] |Shortened from エキストラクト (''ekisutorakuto''). |- |erekishiteito <ref name="Loveday"/> |エレキシテイト |[[wikt:elektriciteit#Dutch|elektriciteit]] |[[electricity]] |Obsolete, replaced by 電気 (''denki''). |- |[[erekiteru]] <ref name="Sanseido"/> |エレキテル |''corruption of'' [[wikt:elektriciteit#Dutch|elektriciteit]] |[[elekiter]] |A type of generator of static electricity used for electric experiments in the 18th century |- |ēteru <ref name="Loveday">[https://books.google.com/books?id=miK9XJPY3fwC&pg=PA54 ''Language contact in Japan: a socio-linguistic history'' by Leo Loveday, p.54-55]</ref> |エーテル |ether |[[ether]] |From Greek, through Dutch. |- |garasu <ref name="DutchConsulate"/> |ガラス, 硝子 |glas |glass, as in a window | |- |gasu <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ガス, 瓦斯 |gas |[[gas]] | |- |giyaman <ref name="Loveday"/> |ギヤマン |diamant |[[diamond]] |From Greek, through Dutch. |- |gomu <ref name="Loveday"/> |ゴム |gom, gum |[[rubber]] | |- |gorofukuren <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ゴロフクレン, 呉絽服連 |grofgrein |[[grosgrain]] | |- |hamu <ref name="Loveday"/> |ハム |ham |[[ham]] | |- |handon |半ドン, ハンドン |''from the "zon" in'' zondag |half-day; holiday |Compound of Japanese ''[[wikt:半#Japanese|han]]'' (half) and ''[[wikt:ドンタク#Japanese|dontaku]]''. This word is no longer commonly used in Japanese. |- |hatoron <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ハトロン, パトロン |patroon |[[pattern]] | |- |henrūda <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ヘンルーダ |wijnruit |[[Common Rue]] | |- |hetto <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ヘット |[[wikt:vet#Dutch|vet]] |[[beef]] [[tallow]] |Cognate with English ''[[wikt:fat#English|fat]]''. |- |hisuterii |ヒステリー |hysterie |hysteria | |- |hukku <ref name="Loveday"/> |フック |hoek |[[wikt:hook|hook]] |Cognate with English ''[[wikt:hook#English|hook]]''. |- |infuruenza <ref name="Loveday"/> |インフルエンザ |influenza |[[influenza]] |After 1720. More likely borrowed from English. The term originated in [[Italian language|Italian]], and became common worldwide in the 18th century via [[English language|English]]. |- |inki <ref name="Sanseido"/> |インキ |inkt |[[ink]] | |- |kamitsure <ref name="Loveday"/> |カミツレ |kamille |[[camomile]] |From Greek, through Dutch. After 1720. |- |kantera <ref name="Sanseido"/> |カンテラ |candela, kandelaar |[[candela]] | |- |kapitan <ref name="Loveday"/> |カピタン, 甲比丹 |kapitein |[[wiktionary:captain|captain]] |More likely derived from [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] ''[[wikt:capitão#Portuguese|capitão]]''. |- |karan |カラン |kraan |[[tap (valve)|tap]] (UK) / [[faucet]] (Am.) |Cognate with English ''[[wikt:crane#English|crane]]'', from the resemblance of the bird's neck to a faucet pipe. |- |kari <ref name="Sanseido"/> |カリ, カリウム |kali, kalium |[[potassium]] | |- |karuki <ref name="Sanseido"/> |カルキ |kalk |[[Lime (material)|lime]] (''the chemical''), chlorinated lime |Cognate with English ''[[wikt:chalk#English|chalk]]''. |- |katēteru <ref name="Sanseido"/> |カテーテル |katheter |[[catheter]] |From Greek, through Dutch. |- |kechin <ref name="Loveday"/> |ケチン |ketting |[[chain]] |After 1720. Now obsolete (replaced by {{nihongo|鎖|kusari}}). |- |kiruku / koruku <ref name="Sanseido"/> |キルク / コルク |kurk |[[Cork material|cork]] | |- |kōhī <ref name="DutchConsulate"/> |コーヒー, 珈琲 |koffie |[[coffee]] |From Arabic, through Dutch. |- |kokku <ref name="Sanseido"/> |コック |kok |[[cooking|cook]] | |- |koppu <ref name="Loveday"/> |コップ |kop |[[cup]] |Reinforcement of Portuguese ''copo''. |- |konpasu <ref name="Loveday"/> |コンパス |kompas |[[compass]] | |- |korera <ref name="Sanseido"/> |コレラ |cholera |[[cholera]] |From Greek, through Dutch. |- |kureosōto <ref name="Sanseido"/> |クレオソート |creosoot |[[creosote]] | |- |madorosu <ref name="Loveday"/> |マドロス |matroos |[[sailor]] | |- |masuto <ref name="Loveday"/> |マスト |mast |[[mast (sailing)|mast]] | |- |mesu <ref name="Loveday"/> |メス |[[wikt:mes#Dutch|mes]] |[[scalpel]] |After 1720. |- |moruhine <ref name="Loveday"/> |モルヒネ |morfine |[[morphine]] |After 1720. |- |morumotto<ref name="Gleeson"/> |モルモット |marmot |[[Guinea pig]]; [[marmot]] | |- |oburāto <ref name="Sanseido"/> |オブラート |oblaat |[[oblaat]] |Also listed in some Japanese sources as deriving from the cognate German term ''[[wikt:Oblate#German|Oblate]]''. |- |orugōru <ref name="DutchConsulate"/> |オルゴール |(orgel) muziekdoos |([[organ (music)|organ]]) music box |- |penki <ref name="Gleeson"/> |ペンキ |pek, pik |house [[paint]] | |- |pesuto <ref name="Loveday"/> |ペスト |pest |[[black death]] |After 1720. |- |pinto <ref name="Gleeson"/> |ピント |punt |[[wikt:focus|focus]] |Shortened from the longer term ''[[wikt:brandpunt#Dutch|brandpunt]]''. |- |pisutoru <ref name="DutchConsulate"/> |ピストル |pistool |[[pistol]] | |- |ponpu <ref name="Loveday"/> |ポンプ |pomp |[[pump]] |After 1720. |- |ponzu <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ポン酢 |pons |[[ponzu]] |The Dutch term ''pons'' for the beverage was [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/cali003nieu01_01/cali003nieu01_01_0019.php#p0699 already obsolescent by 1864], and was eventually superseded by the term ''punsch'' or ''punch''. |- |[[randoseru]] <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ランドセル |ransel |[[backpack]] |From German ''Ränzel'' or Low German ''rensel'', through Dutch. |- |ranpu <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ランプ, 洋灯 |lamp |[[lamp (disambiguation)|lamp]] |From Greek, through Dutch. |- |retoruto <ref name="Sanseido"/> |レトルト |retort |[[retort]] | |- |renzu <ref name="Sanseido"/> |レンズ |lens |[[Lens (optics)|lens]] | |- |safuran <ref name="Sanseido"/> |サフラン |saffraan |[[saffron]] | |- |saten <ref name="Sanseido"/> |サテン |satijn |[[satin]] | |- |seimi <ref name="Sanseido"/> |セイミ, 舎密 |chemie |[[chemistry]] |Now obsolete, replaced by [[wikt:化学#Japanese|化学]] (''kagaku''). |- |shian <ref name="Sanseido"/> |シアン |cyaan |[[cyan]] | |- |shiroppu <ref name="Sanseido"/> |シロップ |siroop |[[syrup]] | |- |sukoppu <ref name="Gleeson">[https://books.google.com/books?id=UzEDpHTQlbcC&pg=PA36 Gleeson ''Introduction to written Japanese, katakana'' p.36]</ref> |スコップ |schop |[[trowel]] |Cognate with English ''[[wikt:scoop#English|scoop]]''. |- |supoito <ref name="Sanseido"/> |スポイト |spuit |[[syringe]] |Cognate with English ''[[wikt:spout#English|spout]]''. |- |tarumomētoru <ref name="Loveday"/> |タルモメートル |thermometer |[[thermometer]] |From French, through Dutch. After 1720. Now obsolete (replaced by {{nihongo|[[wikt:体温計#Japanese|体温計]]|taionkei}}) |- |teresukoppu <ref name="Loveday"/> |テレスコップ |telescoop |[[telescope]] |From Italian and Modern Latin, through Dutch. After 1720. Replaced by {{nihongo|[[wikt:望遠鏡#Japanese|望遠鏡]]|bōenkyō}}. |- |yojiumu <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ヨジウム |jodium |[[iodine]] | |- |zukku <ref name="Sanseido"/> |ズック |doek |[[canvas]] |Cognate with English ''[[wikt:duck#English|duck]]'' (“piece of cloth”). |}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Gwynfor Evans |image = File:Gwynfor Evans.jpg |caption = Evans in 1951 |office = President of [[Plaid Cymru]] |honorific-suffix = |predecessor = [[Abi Williams]] |successor = [[Dafydd Wigley]] |term_start = 1945 |term_end = 1981 |office1 = [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]]
for [[Carmarthen (UK Parliament constituency)|Carmarthen]] |term_start1 = 14 July 1966 |term_end1 = 18 June 1970 |predecessor1 = [[Megan Lloyd George]] |successor1 = [[Gwynoro Jones]] |term_start2 = 10 October 1974 |term_end2 = 3 May 1979 |predecessor2 = [[Gwynoro Jones]] |successor2 = [[Roger Thomas (British politician)|Roger Thomas]] |birthname = Gwynfor Richard Evans |birth_date = {{birth date|1912|9|1|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Barry, Wales|Barry]], Wales |death_date = {{death date and age|2005|4|21|1912|9|1|df=y}} |death_place = [[Pencarreg]], [[Carmarthenshire]], Wales |spouse = {{marriage|Rhiannon Prys Thomas|1941|2005}} |children = 7 |nationality = [[Welsh people|Welsh]] |party = [[Plaid Cymru]] |alma_mater = [[University of Wales, Aberystwyth]]
[[St John's College, Oxford]] }} '''Gwynfor Richard Evans''' (1 September 1912 – 21 April 2005) was a Welsh politician, lawyer and author. He was President of the Welsh political party [[Plaid Cymru]] for thirty six years and was the first [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]] to represent it at [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Westminster]], which he did twice, from 1966 to 1970, and again from 1974 to 1979. ==Early life== Gwynfor Evans was born in [[Barry, Wales|Barry]], near [[Cardiff]], to Dan Evans and Catherine Richard. He had a brother named Alcwyn, and a sister named Ceridwen. His father ran a chain of shops in Barry, and his mother a china shop. His mother was a fluent Welsh speaker. As a boy, he was educated at Gladstone Road School. Later on he was educated at Barry County School, where he was captain of the school's cricket and hockey teams. At the school he began learning the [[Welsh language]], but did not become fully fluent until the age of seventeen. Evans studied at the [[University of Wales, Aberystwyth]] and at [[St John's College, Oxford]], from where he qualified as a lawyer. During his time at St John's, he became a member of the [[Dafydd ap Gwilym]] society there. He was also a [[Market gardening|market garden]]er. He was a teenager when the Welsh nationalist party [[Plaid Cymru]] was founded in 1925, and he founded a branch of the party while he was at Oxford. He became the party's president in 1945 and retained the office until 1981. A [[pacifism|pacifist]], he became active in Heddychwyr Cymru, a Welsh organisation closely associated with the [[Peace Pledge Union]], serving as secretary and editor of a series of pamphlets throughout the [[Second World War]]. A committed Christian also, he declared himself a [[conscientious objector]], and was required to appear before a tribunal which, recognising the firmness of his beliefs, registered him unconditionally. Evans is credited with keeping Plaid Cymru going through the lean years of the 1940s and 1950s. In the 1950s, he campaigned unsuccessfully for a [[Welsh parliament]], and failed to prevent the damming of the [[Tryweryn]] River and consequent inundation of the Welsh-speaking community of [[Capel Celyn]] to supply the city of [[Liverpool]] with water, a ''cause célèbre'' in Wales in the early 1960s. In 1962, [[Wales West and North Television]], a group in which Evans was one of the leading figures, won the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] franchise for western and northern Wales, but the venture failed because of financial difficulties, and the company was merged with [[Television Wales and the West]], with western and northern Wales merged with the rest of Wales and the West of England, as a separate sub-region.{{cite web|last=Rogers|first=Jeremy|title=WWN History|url=http://www.users.zetnet.co.uk/itw/WWN/history.html|work=Independent TeleWeb|accessdate=25 August 2013}} ==Electoral record== ===Local Government and first parliamentary contests=== [[File:1959 Election in Merioneth.jpg|right|thumb|Evans speaking in Merioneth, during the [[United Kingdom general election, 1959|1959 UK Election]]]] Evans was elected to [[Carmarthenshire]] County Council in 1949, keeping his seat for the next 25 years, usually as the lone Plaid Cymru representative, acquiring the nickname "Evans dual carriageway" for his emphasis on improving transport links. In [[1973 Dyfed County Council election|1973]], following the abolition of Carmarthenshire County Council, Evans failed to be elected to the new Dyfed County Council.{{cite news|newspaper=Western Mail|date=13 April 1973}} Evans contested [[Merioneth (UK Parliament constituency)|Merioneth]] at the general elections of [[United Kingdom general election, 1945|1945]], [[United Kingdom general election, 1950|1950]], [[United Kingdom general election, 1955|1955]] and [[United Kingdom general election, 1959|1959]], and the [[Aberdare by-election, 1954]]. ===Carmarthen by-election, 1966=== In 1964 Evans transferred his candidature to Carmarthen. On 14 July 1966, Evans won the parliamentary seat of [[Carmarthen (UK Parliament constituency)|Carmarthen]] from [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] in a by-election caused by the death of Lady [[Megan Lloyd George]], daughter of the former [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] Prime Minister, [[David Lloyd George]], having come third in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1966|general election]] just a few weeks before. He had also contested the seat at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1964|1964 general election]]. His by-election victory is regarded as a seminal moment for Plaid Cymru. He was shown around the House of Commons by fellow pacifist [[Emrys Hughes]], the son-in-law of [[Keir Hardie]]; on pointing out the Welsh Labour table in the Commons' tea room, Hughes warned him, "You'd better not sit down there, your name's mud among that lot."http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,60-1579591,00.html ===Later electoral record=== In the [[United Kingdom general election, 1970|1970 general election]] Evans lost his Carmarthen seat to [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]'s [[Gwynoro Jones]] and failed to regain it in the [[United Kingdom general election, February 1974|February 1974 general election]] by only three votes. He regained the seat, with a majority of 3,640 votes, in the [[United Kingdom general election, October 1974|October 1974 general election]], when he returned to Parliament accompanied by two other Plaid Cymru MPs, [[Dafydd Wigley]] and [[Dafydd Elis Thomas]]. Evans lost Carmarthen once more at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979 general election]], to [[Roger Thomas (British politician)|Dr Roger Thomas]] (also Labour). He was unsuccessful in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|1983 general election]], and did not contest any further elections. ==Career as an MP== In the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], Evans was true to his pacifist principles in being one of the few MPs to oppose the British government's support of the Nigerian federal government with supplies of weapons in the civil war against [[Biafra]] (1967–1970). He also opposed the [[Vietnam War]]: after being denied entry to the country as part of an inspection group, he instead protested outside a US air base in [[Thailand]]. Evans was the first (and last) president of the [[Celtic League (political organisation)|Celtic League]] 1961–71. Dr. [[Robert McIntyre]] of the [[Scottish National Party|SNP]] was vice-president at the time. ==Later life== In 1980, his threat to go on [[hunger strike]], after the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] government reneged on its election promise of a [[Welsh language]] television channel, was instrumental in bringing about an early U-turn on the part of [[Margaret Thatcher]], and [[S4C]] began broadcasting on 1 November 1982.https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-12062288 In his political retirement he became a prolific writer, mainly on Welsh subjects and writing in Welsh with simultaneous or later English editions. His work ''Aros Mae'' (''It Endures'') (published 1971), a comprehensive history of Wales, and the English-language version ''Land of my Fathers: 2000 Years of Welsh History'' (published 1974), had already become best-sellers. ==Personal life== In 1941 Evans married Rhiannon Prys Thomas, who survived him by nine months, dying on 13 January 2006. They had seven children.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/mid/4610138.stm Their daughter, [[Meinir Ffransis|Meinir]], became a prominent Welsh-language activist, and married [[Ffred Ffransis]]. ==Death== On 21 April 2005, Evans died at his home in [[Pencarreg]], at the age of 92.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/2002565.stm[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/gwynfor-evans-495883.html]https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,,1465990,00.htmlhttp://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,60-1579591,00.htmlhttps://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2005/04/22/db2201.xml&sSheet=/portal/2005/04/22/ixportal.html ===Tributes=== [[File:Gwynfor Evans memorial - geograph.org.uk - 452200.jpg|thumb|Gwynfor Evans memorial, on the approach to Garn Goch hillfort, near [[Llandeilo]]]] On his death the Welsh political establishment united in paying its respects to Gwynfor Evans: *''"Without Gwynfor Evans at the helm Plaid Cymru may not have survived to see electoral success in later years. His influence was felt beyond the confines of party politics. Wales would not be the nation it is today — perhaps would not be counted as a nation at all — if not for Gwynfor Evans."'' — [[Dafydd Iwan]], President of Plaid Cymru. *''"Although his relationships with Labour MPs were not always positive, there is no gainsaying his massive contribution to Welsh public life, and particularly in raising the profile of Wales and Welsh issues throughout his long career in Welsh and British politics."'' – [[Rhodri Morgan]], [[First Minister of Wales|First Minister]] of the [[Welsh Government]] ([[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]). *''"Gwynfor Evans made a distinguished contribution to Welsh public life and will be remembered particularly for his advancement of the Welsh language."'' – [[Peter Hain]], [[Secretary of State for Wales]] (Labour). *''"Wales has lost one of its most significant figures of modern times. Gwynfor Evans was a highly respected figure who made a major contribution to Welsh politics. His record on delivering Welsh language broadcasting for Wales is of particular importance."'' – [[Nick Bourne]], Leader of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Welsh Conservative Party]]. *''"Gwynfor served his party well and was able to bring them into electoral success. He earned respect from across the political spectrum. His passing marks the end of a chapter in Welsh political history".'' – [[Mike German, Baron German|Mike German]], Leader of the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Welsh Liberal Democrats]]. *A campaign has been launched to build a permanent monument to Gwynfor Evans in Carmarthen. In 2005 it was suggested that a statue be erected in Nott Square in the town, replacing that of [[William Nott (British general)|Sir William Nott]].''Icons of Wales'', 2012 booklet published jointly by the [[Open University]] and [[BBC Wales]] *A campaign by local primary school teacher Gwenno Hughes to establish a permanent memorial to Gwynfor Evans in the town of his birth culminated in the unveiling of a bronze bust created by the sculptor John Meirion Morris at [[Barry, Vale of Glamorgan|Barry]] Library in 2010. The cost of the memorial was raised by the staff of the local school [[Baruc|Ysgol Gymraeg Sant Baruc]]. ==Bibliography== *''Aros Mae'' (1971) (English version: ''Land of my Fathers: 2000 Years of Welsh History'' (1974) {{ISBN|0-903701-03-0}}) *''Byw neu farw? : y frwydr dros yr iaith a'r Sianel deledu gymraeg / Life or death? : the struggle for the language and a Welsh TV channel '' (1980 {{ISBN|0-905077-12-1}}, bilingual text) *''Diwedd Prydeindod'' (1981, {{ISBN|0-86243-018-6}}) *Autobiography: ''Bywyd Cymro'' (1982) (English version: ''For the Sake of Wales'' (1986) {{ISBN|1-86057-021-6}}) *''The Fight for Welsh Freedom'' (2000, {{ISBN|0-86243-515-3}}) *''Cymru o Hud'' (2001, {{ISBN|0-86243-545-5}}) (English version: ''Eternal Wales'' (2001) {{ISBN|0-86243-608-7}}) ==See also== *[[Carmarthen by-election, 1966]] *[[Royal Commission on the Constitution (United Kingdom)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Wikiquote}} *{{Hansard-contribs | mr-gwynfor-evans | Gwynfor Evans }} * [http://www.gwynfor.net/ Gwynfor Evans Website – run by his family] {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{succession box | title = Member of Parliament for [[Carmarthen (UK Parliament constituency)|Carmarthen]] | years = 1966–1970 | before = [[Megan Lloyd George]] | after = [[Gwynoro Jones]] }} {{succession box | title = Member of Parliament for [[Carmarthen (UK Parliament constituency)|Carmarthen]] | years = 1974–1979 | before = [[Gwynoro Jones]] | after = [[Roger Thomas (British politician)|Roger Thomas]] }} {{s-ppo}} {{succession box | title = President of [[Plaid Cymru]] | years = 1945–1981 | before = [[Abi Williams]] | after = [[Dafydd Wigley]] }} {{succession box | title = Honorary President of [[Plaid Cymru]] | years = 1982–2005 | before = Position created | after = [[Dafydd Wigley]] }} {{s-end}} {{Plaid Cymru}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Evans, Gwynfor}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] Oxford]] [[Category:Plaid Cymru councillors]] [[Category:Leaders of Plaid Cymru]] [[Category:Plaid Cymru MPs]] [[Category:Members of Carmarthenshire County Council]] [[Category:Welsh-language activists]] [[Category:Welsh-language writers]] [[Category:Welsh-speaking politicians]] [[Category:Welsh writers]] [[Category:UK MPs 1966–70]] [[Category:UK MPs 1974–79]] [[Category:Welsh pacifists]] revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{one source|date=January 2013}} '''Hermogenes Ilagan''' (19 April 1873 in [[Balagtas, Bulacan|Bigaa, Bulacan]] – 27 February 1943) was a [[Philippines|Filipino]] [[tenor]], writer, stage actor, and playwright. He was a [[Lineal descendant|descendant]] of [[Francisco Baltazar]]. His talent in singing made him popular in the field of [[theater arts]]. He became known as the Father of [[Tagalog Zarzuela]] and the Father of [[Philippine Zarzuela]].<ref name=Panitikan>{{cite web|url=http://panitikan.com.ph/authors/i/hilagan.htm|title=Hermogenes Ilagan|publisher=panitikan.com.ph|accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref>
==Career== Ilagan was a ''[[tiple]]'' ([[boy soprano|treble]] or [[soprano]]) and lead singer for a church in Bigaa, Bulacan. Because of Ilagan's talent, a [[parish priest]] in Bigaa, Bulacan brought Ilagan and his family to [[Manila]]. He became the singer for the [[Santa Cruz Church (Manila)|Santa Cruz Church]]. In return, Ilagan was able to study at the [[Ateneo de Manila University|Ateneo Municipal de Manila]] (now known as Ateneo de Manila University). Although not able to finish schooling, Ilagan became a member of a [[zarzuela]] troupe (theater performers) from Spain. During the [[Spanish–American War]], the Spanish performers went back to Spain, but Ilagan maintained his liking for the zarzuela, and later pioneered productions of stage drama in the form of Philippine zarzuelas. His forty years of involvement in the field of zarzuela created the period known as the Golden Age of Philippine Theater.<ref name=Panitikan /> In 1902, Ilagan established the Compania Lirico-Dramatica Tagala de Gatchalian y Ilagan, also known as Compania Ilagan, the first zarzuela troupe in the Philippines. Ilagan's zarzuelas have melodramatic, comic, romantic, and political qualities.<ref name=Panitikan />
==Works== Among the zarzuelas that Ilagan wrote and produced were:<ref name=Panitikan/>
*''Ang Buhay nga Naman'' (That's How Life Is) *''Ang Buwan ng Oktubre'' (The Month of October) *''Bill de Divorcio'' (Divorce Bill) *''Dahil kay Ina'' (Because of Mother) *''Dalagang Bukid'' (Country Maiden) *''Dalawang Hangal'' (Two Fools) *''Después de Dios, el Dinero'' (After God, the Money) *''Ilaw ng Katotohanan'' (Light of Truth) *''Kagalingan ng Bayan'' (Country's Benefit) *''Venus'' (Ang Operang Putol) (Venus, The Incomplete Opera) *''Wagas na Pag-ibig'' (True Love) *''Sangla ni Rita, isang Uno't Cero'' (Rita's [[Pledge (law)|Pawnage]], a One and [a] Zero) *''Centro Pericultura'' ([[Periculture]] Center) *''Panarak ni Rosa'' (alternatively known as ''Punyal ni Rosa'') (Rosa's Dagger) *''Lucha Electoral'' (Electoral Fight)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer]] --> | name = Johannes Anyuru | image = Johannes Anyuru 2010.jpg | caption = Johannes Anyuru in 2010. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|3|23|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Borås]], Sweden | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Swedish | spouses = | awards = | notablework = ''[[Städerna inuti Hall]]'' | period = 2003– }}
'''Johannes Anyuru''' (born 23 March 1979) is a Swedish poet and author.
==Biography== Anyuru was born in [[Borås]].<ref>http://www.svt.se/nyheter/regionalt/smalandsnytt/vaxjo-johannes-anyuru-sommarvard-i-p1</ref> His father is from [[Uganda]] and his mother is Swedish.<ref>SVT 1: ''Babel'' 9 September 2010</ref>
He debuted in 2003 with ''Det är bara gudarna som är nya'' (Only The Gods Are New), a poetry collection. In this collection of poems used [[Homer]]'s epic [[Iliad]] as a background and inspiration for the portrayal of [[immigrant]] neighborhoods. A place that is often mentioned in his poetry is the area around ''Mörners road'' in [[Växjö]], where Anyuru lived as a child.<ref>{{cite web|author=Fanny Söderbäck |url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/gamla-gudar-och-nya-1.194714 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120731182705/http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/gamla-gudar-och-nya-1.194714 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 July 2012 |title=Gamla gudar och nya |language=sv |publisher=DN.se |date=7 July 2003 |accessdate=28 August 2010 }}</ref> Reviews of this book linked his style to both older contemporary Swedish poets as [[Göran Sonnevi]] or [[Tomas Tranströmer]], and hip hop band [[The Latin Kings (hip hop group)|The Latin Kings]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tidningenkulturen.se/index.php/13-litteratur/litteratur-kritik/5079-litteratur-johannes-anyuru-staederna-inuti-hall |title= Litteratur: Johannes Anyuru, Städerna inuti Hall |last=Fries |first=Jonna |date=22 September 2009 |website=tidningenkulturen.se |language=Swedish |access-date=1 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref> Anyurus second poetry collection, ''Omega'', is a much more downbeat since it deals with the loss of a close friend to cancer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/kulturnoje/litteratur/varifran-och-varthan_31361.svd |title=Recension: Anyuru, Johannes - Omega (Övrigt) | Litteratur | SvD |language=sv |publisher=Svd.se |date= |accessdate=28 August 2010}}</ref> Anyurus third collection, ''Städerna inuti Hall'' (The Cities Inside Hall)<ref>{{cite web|author=Johannes Anyuru |url=http://www.dn.se/dnbok/utdrag-ur-staderna-inuti-hall-s-27-30/ |title=Utdrag ur "Städerna inuti Hall" s. 27-30 |language=sv |publisher=DN.se |date=16 January 2010 |accessdate=28 August 2010}}</ref> was published in 2009 and describes sad socio-political landscape.
His fourth book ''Skulle jag dö under andra himlar'' (If I Were to Die Under Other Skies)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bokus.com/bok/9789113022086/skulle-jag-do-under-andra-himlar/ |title=Skulle jag dö under andra himlar - Johannes Anyuru - Bokus bokhandel |publisher=Bokus.com |date=12 August 2010 |accessdate=28 August 2010|language=Swedish}}</ref> is not a poetry book, but [[prose]].
He has also worked with [[spoken word]] as part of the group ''Broken Word'' and a touring performance with [[Riksteatern|National Theatre Company]] called Abstrakt rap. Both projects has been released as CD's.<ref>{{cite web|author=Andreas Ekström |url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/poeten-som-rappar-orimmat-1.324767 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729082323/http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/poeten-som-rappar-orimmat-1.324767 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 July 2012 |title=Poeten som rappar orimmat |language=sv |publisher=DN.se |date=10 November 2004 |accessdate=28 August 2010 }}</ref>
In December 2009 he debuted with his first play ''Förvaret'' (Defence), at Gothenburg City Theatre, co-written with Aleksander Motturi.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ingegärd Waaranperä ingegard.waaranpera@dn.se |url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/scenrecensioner/forvaret-pa-nya-studion-goteborgs-stadsteater-1.1013619 |title="Förvaret" på Nya Studion Göteborgs Stadsteater |language=sv |publisher=DN.se |date=13 December 2009 |accessdate=28 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091217012257/http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/scenrecensioner/forvaret-pa-nya-studion-goteborgs-stadsteater-1.1013619 |archivedate=17 December 2009 |df= }}</ref>
During the summer of 2010, he was one of several hosts of legendary radio program [[Sommar (radio program)|Sommar]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/avsnitt/126298?programid=2071 |title=Johannes Anyuru - Sommar i P1 | Sveriges Radio |publisher=Sverigesradio.se |date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=28 August 2010}}</ref>
==Bibliography== *''Det är bara gudarna som är nya'' (poetry collection, 2003) *''Omega'' (poetry collection, 2005) *''Städerna inuti Hall'' (poetry collection, 2009) *''Skulle jag dö under andra himlar'' (novel, 2010) *''En storm kom från paradiset'' (novel, 2012) *''A Storm Blew in From Paradise'' (novel, translated into English by Rachel Willson-Broyles, 2015) *''De kommer att drunkna i sina mödrars tårar'' (novel, 2017) == Honours == * ''[[Nöjesguiden]] Magazine'' award for best read 2003 * ''Guldprinsen'' prize 2003 * ''Kallebergers scholarship'' 2005 * ''Spingo-scholarship'' 2005 * ''[[Augustpriset]] nominee'' 2012, ''winner'' 2017
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.dn.se/dnbok/nominerad-till-dns-kulturpris-2010-johannes-anyuru-1.1027590
