revision.text:
[[Image:Oxirinacs0.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Olga Xirinacs Díaz]]
'''Olga Xirinacs Díaz''' (born 1936) is a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] writer and piano teacher. During her literary career, she has written poetry, drama, tales and essays. She was born in [[Tarragona]] ([[Catalonia]], [[Spain]]), where she still lives and works.
Xirinacs often writes in the daily press: her articles have been published in ''[[La Vanguardia]], Avui'', and'' Foc Nou'', amongst others. She has given narrative courses in the Aula de Lletres and in [[Barcelona]]'s Pompeu Fabra University.
Some of her books have won prestigious Catalan literature awards, including the [[Premi Sant Jordi de novel·la|Sant Jordi]], Sant Joan, Josep Plà, Ramon Llull and the Carles Riba prizes.
She has published more than three hundred tales, 250 for adults and around 50 for children. She is the only female “[[Floral Games#Mestres en Gai Saber|Mestra en Gai Saber]]” (Master in the Art of Poetry) of the [[Jocs Florals]] (Literary Contest) after [[Mercè Rodoreda]] Gurgui. In 1990, the [[Generalitat de Catalunya]] awarded her the [[Creu de Sant Jordi]]. She is a member of Association of Catalan-Language Writers.
==Prose works==
* ''Música de cambra'' (Chamber music) Barcelona 1982. * ''Interior amb difunts'' (Inside Corpses), Josep Pla Prize, 1982. Barcelona 1983. * ''La mostela africana i altres contes'' (The African weasel and other tales) Barcelona 1985. * ''Al meu cap una llosa'' (On my Head, a Tombstone) [[Premi Sant Jordi de novel·la|Sant Jordi Prize]], 1984 and Serra d'Or Critics Prize for the Novel. Barcelona 1985. *''Zona marítima'' (Maritime Area), Ramon Llull Novel Prize, 1986. Barcelona 1986. * ''Relats de mort i altres matèries'' (Stories of death and other stuff) Barcelona 1988. * ''Mar de fons'' (Deep sea). Barcelona 1988. * ''Tempesta d'hivern'' (Winter storm). Barcelona 1990. * ''Enterraments lleugers'' (Shallow Interments), Sant Joan Prize, 1990. Barcelona 1991. * ''Cerimònia privada'' (Private ceremony). Barcelona 1993. * ''Josep Sala''. Tarragona 1993. * ''Sense malícia'' (Without wickedness), City of Palma Novel Prize, 1993. Barcelona 1993 * ''Sucant el melindro''. (Dipping the [[sponge biscuit]]). Barcelona 1996. * ''La Via Augusta. Vint pobles fan el Tarragonès. De Llevant a Ponent''. (August Way . Twenty villages that make Tarragones. From West to East)Barcelona 1997. * ''Viatge d’aigua. Un passeig per la Costa Daurada'' (Water travel. A walk through Costa Daurada). Barcelona 1999. * ''La tarda a Venècia'' (An afternoon in Venice). Barcelona 1999. * ''L’home que mossegava les dones'' (The man who bit women). Barcelona 2000. * ''Pavana per un tauró'' (Mourning music for a Shark). Barcelona 2001. * ''No jugueu al cementiri'' (Do not play in the cemetery). Thriller Prize 2001. Barcelona 2002. * ''Els 7 pecats capitals. La peresa – eròtica-“ (The 7 capital sins. The erotic laziness). Barcelona 2002. * ''Setmana de difunts'' (Dead week). Barcelona 2003 * ''El viatge. Dietari 1986-1990'' (The voyage: Diary 1986-1990). Barcelona 2004. * ''El hijo del tejedor'' (The weaver's son). Spanish language. Barcelona 2006. * ''Trens'' (Trains). Barcelona 2006
==Poetic works==
* ''Botons de tiges grises'' (Buttons from grey ítems). Barcelona 1977. * ''Clau de blau (Tarraconis vrit amor)'' (The Blue Key). Tarragona 1978. * ''Llençol de noces'' (Wedding bedsheet). Barcelona 1979. * ''Tramada'' (Ploted) Collective with the group ''Espiadimonis''. Tarragona 1980. * ''Preparo el te sota palmeres roges''( I prepare the tea under red palm trees). Caravel·la Prize, 1980. Barcelona 1981. * ''Versifonies''. Collective with the group ''Espiadimonis'' (Versymphonies).Tarragona 1987. * ''Llavis que dansen'' (Lips that dance). Barcelona 1987. * ''La pluja sobre els palaus'' ( The rain over the palaces). Barcelona 1990. * ''La muralla''. (The wall). Barcelona 1993. * ''Mansardes''. (Mansards) Collective with the group ''Espiadimonis''. Tarragona 1997. * ''Grills de mandarina''. (Mandari orange segments). Lleida 2004. * ''El sol a les vinyes''. (The Sun in the vineyards. Il vangelo, Pasolini in memoriam). Bilingual edition. Barcelona 2005 * ''Eterna''. (Eternal). Bilingual edition Catalan/Spanish. Barcelona 2006
==Works for children==
* ''Marina''. Illustrated by [[Asun Balzola]]. Barcelona 1986. * ''Patates fregides''. (Fried potatoes). Illustrated byCarme Solé. Barcelona 1994. * ''Sóc un arbre''. (I’m a tree). Illustrated by Asun Balzola. Barcelona 1994. * ''El far del capità''. (The captain’s lighthouse). Illustrated by Carme Solé. Barcelona 1994. * ''Xocolata''. (Chocolate) Barcelona 1994. * ''El meu pare és capità'' (My father is a captain). Illustrated by Gemma Sales. Barcelona 1995. * ''Final d’estiu''. (Summer’s end) Barcelona 1996. * ''Wendy torna a volar''. (Wendy flies again)Barcelona 1996. * ''El vol de Dràcula''. (Dracula’s fly)Illustrated by Francesc Infante. Barcelona 1996. * ''Mòmies''. (Mummies) Barcelona 1996. * ''Triangles mortals o la sala dels difunts'' (Mortal triangles or the corpses' room). Illustrated by Mercè Canals. Barcelona 1998. * ''Marina / Cavall de mar''. (Marina/Seahorse). Illustrated by Asun Balzola. Barcelona 1998. * ''La núvia adormida''. (The sleeping bride) Barcelona 1998. * ''La Vaca Xoriça''. (Xoriça caw). Illustrated by Laia Soler. Barcelona 1998. * ''Un cadàver per sopar''. (A corpse for dinner) City of Badalona Prize for Young People's Narrative, 2000. Barcelona 2000. * ''L’escrivent de làpides''. (The tombstone court clerk) Barcelona 2002.
== Translated works ==
'''Spanish'''
* ''Zona marítima''. (Maritime zone). Translated by Sara Pujol. Barcelona 1987. * ''El faro del capitán''. (The captain’s lighthouse). Author’s translation. Madrid 1994. * ''Fin de verano''. (Summer’s end). Author’s translation. Madrid 1996. * ''El vuelo de drácula''. (Dracula’s fly). Author’s translation. Madrid, 1996. * ''El árbol de mi patio''.(The tree from my courtyard). Asun Balzola's drawings. Author’s translation. Barcelona, 1996. * ''Marina y Caballito de mar''. (Marina and Sea horse). Author’s translation. Madrid, 1998. * ''La novia dormida''.(the Asleep bride) Author’s translation. Barcelona, 1998. * ''El escribiente de lápidas''. (The tombstone court clerk) Translated by Pau Joan Hernàndez. Barcelona, 2002.
'''Other languages'''
* Many tales have been translated into German, Basque, Spanish and Russian * [http://www.sola-sole.com/xirin.htm ''Lips that dance''] (poetry) translated to English by Hillary J Gardner. Washington University. *Poetry translated to French published in some French and Canadian magazines. * ''Jardines sobre el mar'' (Gardens over the sea) Bilingual anthology of poetry. Translated to Russian by Elena Zernova. Sant Petersburg University. 2003
==External links== * [http://olgaxirinacs.blogspot.com/ Author's personal blog] * [http://www.escriptors.cat/autors/xirinacso/ Author's pages of Association of Catalan-Language Writers] * [http://www.mcu.es/cgi-brs/BasesHTML/isbn/BRSCGI?CMD=VERLST&CONF=AEISPA.cnf&BASE=ISBN&DOCS=1-75&SORT=-T353:4&EXPBUS=(DISPONIBLE).WDIS.+%26+(XIRINACS++OLGA+).WAUT.&QUERY=(DISPONIBLE).WDIS.+%26+(XIRINACS++OLGA+).WAUT.. Spanish Agency of publish books (ISBN)]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051016234813/http://www.premisliteraris.org/xirinacs.html Tarragona's writers. ] * [http://www.sola-sole.com/xirin.htm Lips that dance: translation] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071001011257/http://cultura.gencat.net/bpt/actual/xirinacs.htm Olga Xirinacs. File compiled by the Public Library of Tarragona (Biblioteca Pública de Tarragona)]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Xirinacs Diaz, Olga}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Tarragona]] [[Category:Catalan-language writers]] [[Category:Catalan women writers]] [[Category:Catalan poets]] [[Category:Catalan dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Spanish women poets]] [[Category:Women dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Spanish children's writers]] [[Category:Women children's writers]] [[Category:20th-century Spanish poets]] [[Category:21st-century Spanish poets]] [[Category:21st-century women writers]] [[Category:20th-century women writers]]

revision.comment: /* Notable Pas de deux */
revision.text:
{{About|the ballet term|other uses|Pas de deux (disambiguation)}}
[[File:NWFusionPaquitaPas2.jpg|thumb|right|Dancers performing ''[[Paquita]]'' grand pas de deux entrée]]
In [[ballet]], a '''pas de deux''' {{IPA-fr|pɑ d(ə) dø|}} ([[French language|French]], literally "step of two") is a dance [[duet]] in which two dancers, typically a male and a female, perform ballet steps together.<ref name="Bedinghaus" /><ref name="Greskovic" /> The pas de deux is characteristic of classical ballet and can be found in many well-known ballets, including ''[[Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|Sleeping Beauty]]'', ''[[Swan Lake]]'', and ''[[Giselle]]''.<ref name="Bedinghaus" /> It is most often performed by a male and a female (a ''danseur'' and a ''ballerina'') though there are exceptions, such as in the film ''[[White Nights (1985 film)|White Nights]]'', in which a pas de deux is performed by [[Mikhail Baryshnikov]] and [[Gregory Hines]].<ref name="Bedinghaus" />
==Grand pas de deux==
A '''grand pas de deux''' is a structured pas de deux that typically has five parts, consisting of an ''entrée'' (introduction), an ''adagio'', two variations (a solo for each dancer), and a ''coda'' (conclusion).<ref name="Bedinghaus" /> It is effectively a suite of dances that share a common theme, often symbolic of a love story or the partnership inherent in love, with the dancers portraying expressions of affectionate feelings and thoughts between romantic partners.<ref name="Bedinghaus" /><ref name="Greskovic" /><ref name="Cohen" /> It is often considered to be the [[pièce de résistance]] and bravura highlight of a ballet and is usually performed by a leading pair of [[principal dancer]]s.<ref name="Greskovic" />
===Entrée=== A grand pas de deux usually begins with an entrée (literally "entrance"), which serves as a short prelude to and also unequivocally denotes the beginning of the dance suite. During the entrée, the dancers first appear on the [[stage (theatre)|stage]] and, typically with great pageantry, acknowledge each other and position themselves near each other in preparation for the subsequent adagio. Depending on the [[choreography (dance)|choreography]], the ballerina and danseur may enter the stage simultaneously or at different times.
===Adagio=== The ''adagio'' or ''adage'' (meaning "slowly") part of a grand pas de deux features graceful and elaborate [[dance partnering|partnering]] by the dancing pair. In the adagio, the ballerina performs elegant, often slow and sustained movements while the danseur supports her. The danseur, in turn, strives to maintain a display of poise and seemingly effortless strength while providing support for the ballerina. The danseur may support the ballerina in a variety of common ways, including lifting her, holding and steadying her during [[dance turns|turns]], and offering a steady arm or hand for her to use as a "virtual [[barre (ballet)|barre]]" when she performs balancing feats that would be difficult or impossible without assistance.<ref name="Bedinghaus" /><ref name="Kersley" /> Because of this support the adagio is sometimes called ''supported adagio''. <gallery class="center" caption="Examples" mode=nolines heights=150px widths=150px> File:Penché.gif|Penché File:NutcrackerSnowPas.JPG|A partnering lift File:Pirouette .gif|[[Pirouette]]s </gallery>
===Variations=== Upon completion of the adagio, the dancers separate and each dancer, in turn, takes center stage and performs a ''variation'' (a [[solo dance]]).<ref name="Greskovic" /> In general, the variations are intended to showcase spectacular, [[acrobatics|acrobatic]] leaps and turns, as well as the skills and athleticism of the individual dancers. The danseur's variation is usually performed first, followed by the ballerina's variation.
<gallery class="center" caption="Examples" mode=nolines heights=150px widths=150px> File:Tomoaki Nakanome - Don Quichotte, Basile - Prix de Lausanne 2010.jpg File:Chenxin Liu - Don Quichotte, Kitri - Prix de Lausanne 2010-7 edit.jpg </gallery>
===Coda=== The ''coda'' (literally "tail") is the concluding segment of a grand pas de deux. Typically, it is a recapitulation of earlier segments of the grand pas de deux, consisting of elements that are characteristic of the adagio, variations, or both, and ends during a grand musical climax.<ref name="Greskovic" />
==History==
Elements of the grand pas de deux first appeared in the early 18th century as opening acts of operas and ballets in which a couple would perform identical dance steps, sometimes while holding hands. At that time and throughout the [[Baroque]] period, ballet partner dancing was evolving to show more dramatic content. For example, in ''[[The Loves of Mars and Venus]]'' ballet of 1717, Mars (the male dancer) strove to portray gallantry, respect, ardent love and adoration, while Venus showed bashfulness, reciprocal love, and wishful looks.<ref name="Cohen" />
In the late 18th and early 19th centuries a romantic pas de deux emerged that involved closer physical contact, with ballerinas dancing on their toes in the hands of their partners. As the 19th century progressed, the form became a showcase for the skills of the increasingly sophisticated ballerina.
The ballets of the late 19th Century—particularly of those of [[Marius Petipa]]—introduced the concept of the grand pas de deux, which often served as the climax of a scene or an entire performance. This involved a consistent format of entrée and adagio by a pair of leading male and female dancers, followed by virtuosic solos (first by the male and then the female) and a finale.<ref name="Cohen" /> During the 20th century, the grand pas de deux became more integrated with the story of the ballet, with increasingly acrobatic content.<ref name="Cohen" />
==Notable Pas de deux== [[File:Dq1.jpg|right|thumb|190px|Grand Pas de deux from ''[[Don Quixote (ballet)|Don Quixote]]'']] * ''White Swan Pas de deux'', from the second act of ''[[Swan Lake]]'' * ''Black Swan Pas de deux'', from the third act of ''[[Swan Lake]]'' * ''Bluebird Pas de deux'', from the third act of ''[[The Sleeping Beauty Ballet|The Sleeping Beauty]]'' * ''[[Coppélia]] Grand Pas de deux'' * ''[[Tsar Kandavl or Le Roi Candaule|Diane and Actéon]] Pas de deux'', from the ballet ''Le Roi Candaule'' * ''[[Flower Festival in Genzano]] Pas de deux'' * ''[[La Sylphide]] Pas de deux'' * ''[[Le Corsaire]] Pas de deux'' * ''[[Don Quixote (ballet)|Don Quixote]] Grand Pas de deux'' * ''[[The Nutcracker]] Grand Pas de deux'' * ''[[Paquita]] Grand Pas de deux'' * ''[[The Talisman (Petipa/Drigo)|The Talisman]] Pas de deux'' * ''[[Harlequinade]] Pas de deux'' * ''[[La fille mal gardée]] Pas de deux''
==See also== * [[Pas de trois]], a dance for three dancers * [[Pas de quatre (ballet)|Pas de quatre]], a dance for four dancers
==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="Kersley">{{cite book | last = Kersley | first = Leo | title = A Dictionary of Ballet Terms }}</ref> <ref name="Cohen">{{cite book | last = Cohen | first = Selma Jean | title = International Encyclopedia of Dance | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2004 | pages = 105–108 | isbn = }}</ref> <ref name="Greskovic">{{cite book | last = Greskovic | first = Robert | authorlink = | title = Ballet 101: A Complete Guide to Learning and Loving the Ballet | publisher = | pages = 194–195 | isbn = }}</ref> <ref name="Bedinghaus">{{cite web | last = Bedinghaus | first = Treva | title = What is a pas de deux? | publisher = | url = http://dance.about.com/od/ball2/f/Pas_de_Deux.htm | accessdate = 2014-03-11 }}</ref> }}
==External links== {{Commons category-inline|pas de deux}}
==Further reading==
* Richard Elis and Christine Du Boulay, ''Partnering - The fundamentals of pas de deux'', Wyman and sons 1955 * Anton Dolin, ''Pas de deux - The Art of Partnering'', Dover Publications 1969 * Charles R. Schroeder, ''Adagio'', 1971 Regmar Publishing Co. * Kenneth Laws and Cynthia Harvey, ''Physics, Dance and the Pas de Deux'', Schirmer books 1994 * Nikolaij Serebrennikov, Marian Horosko, ''Pas De Deux: A Textbook on Partnering'', University of Florida, 2000 * Suki Schorer, ''On Balanchine Technique'', ''Partnering'' section, p. 383, Knopf 1999, {{ISBN|0-679-45060-2}}
{{Ballet}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Ballet terminology]] [[Category:Partner dance]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/205.215.222.167|205.215.222.167]] ([[User talk:205.215.222.167|talk]]): nonconstructive edits ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Pat Califia | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1954|3|8}} | birth_place = [[Corpus Christi, Texas]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | residence = [[Tampa, Florida]] | alma_mater = [[San Francisco State University]] | other_names = | occupation = [[Writer]], [[family therapy|therapist]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | spouse = }} '''Pat Califia''' (born 1954, formerly also known by the last name '''Califia-Rice''') is an American writer of non-fiction essays about [[human sexuality|sexuality]] and of [[eroticism|erotic]] fiction and poetry.{{cite web |title=Patrick Califia|url=http://www.nndb.com/people/573/000118219/ | website = nndb.com | publisher = [[NNDB|Notable Names Database]] (NNDB) }}{{cite news | last = Marech | first = Rona | title = Radical Transformation | url = http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Radical-Transformation-Writer-Patrick-3303152.php | work = [[San Francisco Chronicle|SF Gate]] | date = October 27, 2000 }} Califia is a [[bisexuality|bisexual]] [[trans man]].{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2003/02/19/califia/|title=Gender-bending|last=Alvear|first=Michael|date=February 19, 2003|work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|accessdate=May 10, 2012}} Prior to [[transitioning (transgender)|transitioning]], he identified as a [[lesbian]] and as such, wrote for many years a [[sex columnist|sex advice column]] for the [[gay men]]'s leather magazine ''[[Drummer (magazine)|Drummer]]''. His writings explore sexuality and [[gender identity]], and have included [[lesbianism in erotica|lesbian erotica]] and works about [[BDSM]] subculture.{{cite web | title = Patrick Califia | url = http://www.lgbthistorymonth.com/www/patrick-califia?tab=biography | website = lgbthistorymonth.com | publisher = LGBT History Month via [[Comcast]] |accessdate=November 14, 2014 }} Califia is a member of the [[third-wave feminism]] movement. ==Early life== {{confusing|date=February 2014}} Califia was born in [[Corpus Christi, Texas]] in 1954 and grew up in Utah in a [[Mormon]] family. His father was a construction worker and his mother was a housewife. Califia was the oldest of six children.{{cite book | last = Prono | first = Luca | title = Encyclopedia of gay and lesbian popular culture | publisher = Greenwood Press | location = Westport, Connecticut | year = 2008 | isbn = 9780313335990 }} [https://books.google.com/?id=Y3FYzMPH2OwC&pg=PA49 Preview.]{{cite news | last = Decter | first = Ann | title = Click: Becoming Feminist | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160301150608/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-625243371.html | archive-date = March 1, 2016 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-625243371.html | date = July 1, 1998 | work = [[Herizons]] | location = Manitoba, Canada | accessdate = May 10, 2012}} Califia has said he did not have a good childhood, claimed that his father was an angry and violent man and his mother a pious woman.{{cite web | title = Patrick Califia | url = http://www.glbtq.com/literature/califia_p.html | website = glbtq.com | publisher = Encyclopedia of GLBTQ Culture | accessdate = November 14, 2014 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141008112738/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/califia_p.html | archivedate = October 8, 2014 }} [http://www.glbtqarchive.com/literature/califia_p_L.pdf Pdf version.] Califia believed in the Mormon religion, and there were elements of [[Mormonism]] in his approach to life. One primary tenet of Mormonism Califia tended to follow was, "if the truth has been revealed to you and you don't speak out, you are culpable for any wrongs that are committed in those realms of life." Califia's sense of difference began when he was a child. He had dreams of becoming a [[train engineer]] which his parents shot down because he was born female. He started [[trans man|transitioning]] in 1999. In the 1970s, Califia's parents had him admitted to a [[psychiatric hospital]], and he dropped out of college (the [[University of Utah]] in [[Salt Lake City]]) due to his mental state. Califia came out as lesbian in 1971 while attending college. He began using the last name ''[[Califia]],''{{citation needed |date=May 2015}} after the mythical female warrior [[Amazons|Amazon]].{{citation | last = Califia | first = Patrick | contribution = Introduction | editor-last = Califia | editor-first = Patrick | title = Macho sluts | page = 35 | publisher = Arsenal Pulp Press | location = Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada | year = 2009 | isbn = 9781551523521 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=gjgsAQAAIAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Introduction Details.] Califia began to evade his parents, and became involved in the [[women's liberation]] and [[anti-war movement]]s. After getting involved in [[consciousness raising]] in the area, he moved to San Francisco in 1973, bringing an interest in [[sex education]] to work on the [[San Francisco Sex Information]] switchboard.{{citation | last = Sides | first = Josh | contribution = When the streets went gay | editor-last = Sides | editor-first = Josh | title = Erotic city: sexual revolutions and the making of modern San Francisco | page = 119 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = New York Oxford | year = 2012 | isbn = 9780199874064 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=WYJezSP8fMoC&pg=PA119 Details.] After moving to San Francisco he began writing for a magazine and joined a lesbian [[separatist]] movement. In 1975 he spoke in favor of [[sadomasochism]] and found himself excluded from the [[lesbian feminist]] community. He was not only excluded from his nuclear family by coming out as a lesbian but also lost his gay family when speaking his opinions. Califia became increasingly involved in [[Sadomasochism|S/M]] activities not only with lesbians but also with gay men. He co-founded the first lesbian S/M group, [[Samois]], in 1978. ==Education== Califia began attending the [[University of Utah]] in [[Salt Lake City]] in 1971. In 1981, he graduated from [[San Francisco State University]] (SFSU) with a [[bachelor of arts]] degree in psychology.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/patrick.califia |title=Patrick Califia |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=October 10, 2013 }} He has also said he has a master's degree.{{cite book | last = Califia | first = Patrick | title = Sex changes: the politics of transgenderism | publisher = Cleis Press | location = San Francisco, California | year = 1997 | isbn = 9781573440721 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=V_mHAAAAIAAJ Details.] ==Career== In 1980, Califia published his first book—''Sapphistry: The Book of Lesbian Sexuality'', a non-fiction work for lesbians which described, in a non-judgmental tone, [[Butch and Femme|butch-femme]] sexuality, and [[BDSM]] safety and practice.{{cite book | last1 = Califia | first1 = Patrick | last2 = Corinne | first2 = Tee | author-link2 = Tee Corinne | title = Sapphistry: the book of lesbian sexuality | publisher = Naiad Press | location = Tallahassee, Florida | year = 1983 | edition = 2nd | isbn = 9780930044473 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=AuxRAQAAIAAJ Details.] Subsequently, he published work in lesbian, gay and [[feminism|feminist]] magazines, including a long-running sex advice column in ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]''.{{Cite journal | last = Fitting | first = Peter | title = Violence and utopia: John Norman and Pat Califia | journal = [[Utopian Studies]] | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | pages = 91–108 | publisher = [[Penn State University Press]] | date = 2000 | jstor = 25702459 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} Califia is "one of earliest champions of lesbian sadomasochistic sex" whose "work has been taught on college campuses across the country and abroad." He has a long history of [[Relational transgression|transgression]], identifying as a [[feminist]], lesbian, and [[transgender]] while also at times finding rejection from those communities "for various infractions." He played what some observers termed a "notable role" in the [[Feminist Sex Wars]] of the 1970s/1980s. The sides were characterized by [[Feminist views on pornography#anti-pornography feminism|anti-porn feminist]] and [[Sex-positive feminism|sex-positive feminist]] groups with disagreements regarding [[Human sexuality|sexuality]], pornography and other forms of sexual representation, prostitution, the role of [[trans woman|trans women]] in the lesbian community, [[lesbian sexual practices]], [[sadomasochism]], and other sexual issues. Califia rejected the "essentialist, feminist ideology – that women are better, more nurturing, more peaceful, more loving, more relationship-oriented and less raunchy in bed," instead advocating for [[BDSM]], "the consensual integration of power, pain, domination and submission into sex." According to the ''San Francisco Chronicle'', many feminists were won over to Califia's views on S/M not from his arguments, but from his erotic fiction: "they read Califia-Rice's S/M fantasies, got turned on and got over it." In 1979, as a student in [[psychology]] at [[San Francisco State University]], his research was published in the ''[[Journal of Homosexuality]]''.{{Cite journal | last = Califia | first = Pat | title = Lesbian sexuality | journal = [[Journal of Homosexuality]] | volume = 4 | issue = 3 | pages = 255–266 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1300/J082v04n03_04 | pmid = 264129 | date = 1979 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1300/J082v04n03_04 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} Califia co-founded [[Samois]], a lesbian-feminist BDSM organization based in San Francisco that existed from 1978 to 1983, and shifted his focus to the lesbian experience of [[BDSM]].{{citation | last = Bronstein | first = Carolyn | contribution = Anti-pornography comes undone: the rise of the feminist pro-sex countermovement | editor-last = Bronstein | editor-first = Carolyn | title = Battling pornography: the American feminist anti-pornography movement, 1976-1986 | page = 288 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge New York | year = 2011 | isbn = 9781107400399 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/?id=EYheMTwz2qIC Details.] The Samois Collective produced, with Califia's contributions, the book, ''[[Coming to Power]]'', published by [[Alyson Publications]].{{citation | last = Hart | first = Lynda | contribution = Notes: Notes to chapter 5 - Bearing (to) Witness | editor-last = Hart | editor-first = Lynda | title = Between the body and the flesh: performing sadomasochism | page = 237 | publisher = Columbia University Press | location = New York | year = 1998 | isbn = 9780231084031 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=7RFB0NB4fscC Details.] :''Quote:'' ::It is interesting to note that after I had written this chapter, Califia and Sweeney's sequel to ''Coming to Power'' was published, entitled ''The Second Coming''. This title's reference to the earlier volume is obvious. But it also strikes me that the theological connotation it carries of a "resurrection" is a concept that is deeply inscribed in s/m practice. Such a "redemptive" grammar, which is pervasive in the literature, could be perceived as pastoralizing in tone, and indeed must be in part. But it also campy and ironic, parodic in one sense and, like all parody carrying with it a certain ambivalent reverence for the model that it both mocks and imitates. ''Coming To Power'', according to editor in chief Heather Findlay of lesbian magazine ''[[Girlfriends (U.S. TV series)|Girlfriends]]'', was "one of the most transformative lesbian books, [foretelling] the end of a certain puritanism that had dominated the community. It was the first articulate defense of lesbian S/M, and that was the end of it." Another book, the ''Lesbian S/M Safety Manual'', won the 1990 [[Bookseller/Diagram Prize for Oddest Title of the Year]].{{cite web | last = Burkardt | first = John | title = The Oddest Book Titles | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160810000940/http://people.sc.fsu.edu/~jburkardt/fun/wordplay/title_oddest.html | archive-date = August 10, 2016 | url = http://people.scs.fsu.edu/~burkardt/fun/wordplay/title_oddest.html | website = people.scs.fsu.edu |publisher= The Department of Scientific Computing, [[Florida State University]] |date=June 1, 2007|accessdate= February 24, 2008 }} In 1992 Califia founded the leatherwomen's quarterly ''Venus Infers'', and published "Feminism, Paedophilia, and Children's Rights" in Vol. 2, No. 4, a special women's issue, of the pro-pedophile scholarly journal ''Paidika''. In 1996 he was co-editor, with Robin Sweeney, of ''The Second Coming: A Leatherdyke Reader'', a sequel to ''Coming to Power''. Califia was writing about [[queer studies]] and [[gender identity]], and coming to terms with these issues on a personal level. At age 45, Califia [[Transitioning (transgender)|transitioned]], taking the name Patrick.{{citation | last = Califia | first = Patrick | contribution = Manliness | editor-last1 = Stryker | editor-first1 = Susan | editor-last2 = Whittle | editor-first2 = Stephen | editor-link1 = Susan Stryker | editor-link2 = Stephen Whittle | title = The transgender studies reader | pages = 434–438 | publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 9780415947091 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} In a 2000 interview, Califia explained that the inspiration for his erotic writings varies; sometimes it is just about having fun, or it can be satire, or exploring a sexuality issue like HIV-positive people [[barebacking]] with the intention of infecting the other person with the virus. In the interview with Rona Marech, Califia is quoted as saying:
It's about me trying to put a human face on that and understand that from the inside out. ...It's about being thought-provoking, hopefully. And I like (presenting issues) that challenge the reader; that are maybe a little scary, maybe hard to think about. ...It's also a way to top a lot of people. In some ways, I get to do a scene with everyone who reads one [sic] my books.
Janet Hardy, of [[Greenery Press]], admires Califia's tenacity, stating, "He's got a phenomenal mind. ...He's willing to get a hold of a thought and follow it through to the end, even if it doesn't feel comfortable." Califia was nominated for the [[Lambda Literary Awards]] for his short-story collection, ''[[Macho Sluts]]'' (1988), his novel, ''Doc and Fluff: The Dystopian Tale of a Girl and Her Biker'' (1990), and a compilation of his columns, ''The Advocate Adviser'' (1991). He is working on a book that discusses the topic of FTM sexuality,{{When|date=May 2015}} and is working on a new set of essays surrounding the topic of BDSM.{{When|date=February 2016}} He has also written vampire books.{{cite book | last = Califia | first = Patrick | title = Mortal companion | publisher = Suspect Thoughts Press | location = San Francisco | year = 2004 | isbn = 9780739448236 }} [https://www.amazon.com/Mortal-Companion-Patrick-Califia/dp/0739448234/ref=sr_1_9?ie=UTF8&qid=1455797319&sr=8-9&keywords=patrick+califia Details.] Califia presented a paper for the [[American Academy of Religion]] conference in Montréal, November 19–22, 2009,{{cite book | last = Kraemer | first = Christine | title = Eros and touch from a pagan perspective: divided for love's sake | publisher = Routledge | location = New York, New York | year = 2013 | isbn = 9780415820189 }} on the gay marriage debate, and how arguments about [[monogamy]] and S/M have been used to try and control the argument. When Califia would travel to Canada, his pornographic works were often seized by Canadian customs, until he fought a court case to allow them to be accepted.{{cite news | last = Cusac | first = Anne-Marie |title=Profile of a sex radical | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150329060002/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-18710719.html | archive-date = March 29, 2015 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-18710719.html |work= [[The Progressive]] | date = October 1, 1996 | accessdate = May 10, 2012}} {{subscription required|date=February 2016|text=partial text|s}} Afterwards, he wrote of his amusement at finding that anti-porn feminist [[Catherine Itzin]]'s book, ''Pornography: Women, Violence and Civil Liberties'', was seized under the very law she had helped to establish, while Califia's books were recognized as acceptable by that law. Califia fought against anti-pornography legislation co-authored by [[Catharine MacKinnon]]. In 2013, he was named by Equality Forum as one of their 31 Icons of the [[LGBT History Month]].{{cite web | title = 2013 Icons Announced: LGBT History Month 2013 Now Online | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160310023401/http://equalityforum.com/lgbt-history-month-2013-icons-announced | archive-date = March 10, 2016 | url = http://www.equalityforum.com/lgbt-history-month-2013-icons-announced | website = equalityforum.com | publisher = Equality Forum | date = 2013 |access-date = 1 February 2016 }} From 2001 to 2011, Califia was licensed in California as a [[family therapy|marriage and family therapist]] (MFT).{{cite web | title = License verification of Pat Califia| url = https://www.breeze.ca.gov/datamart/detailsCADCA.do?selector=false&selectorType=&selectorReturnUrl=&anchor=e010b0d.0.0 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150526070508/https://www.breeze.ca.gov/datamart/detailsCADCA.do?selector=false&selectorType=&selectorReturnUrl=&anchor=e010b0d.0.0 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2015-05-26 | website = Breeze.ca.gov }} ==Personal life== Califia has a son, Blake Califia-Rice (born October 1999), to whom his ex-partner, Matt Rice (now a [[trans man]]), gave birth.{{cite news | last = Alvear | first = Michael | title = Gender-bending | url = http://www.salon.com/2003/02/19/califia/ | date = February 19, 2003 | website = [[Salon (website)|Salon]] |accessdate=November 14, 2014}} Califia has said that since the 1990s, he has had [[fibromyalgia]].{{cite book | last = Sensuous | first = Sadie | title = It's not about the whip: my explorations into love, sex and spirituality in the BDSM scene | page = 157 | publisher = Trafford | location = Victoria, British Columbia, Canada | year = 2003 | isbn = 9781412001830 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=XK2mLUdxzNcC&pg=PT157 Details.] ===Transition=== In 1999, Califia decided to begin [[Hormone replacement therapy (female-to-male)|hormone replacement therapy]] as a part of his transition. Califia had considered [[Sex reassignment surgery|sex reassignment]] in his twenties, but had been hesitant, for one reason, because there were many dangers to the surgery at that time. He also hesitated because his career had been built around a reputation as a lesbian writer and activist. Califia had entered age-related [[menopause|perimenopause]] when he began his transition. He has stated that being a man or a woman was never a good fit for him but sex reassignment seemed to be the most reasonable option. ==Selected bibliography== === Non-fiction === * ''Sapphistry: The Book of Lesbian Sexuality'' (1980) ({{ISBN|978-0-93-004414-5}}) * ''Public Sex: The Culture of Radical Sex'' (1994) ({{ISBN|978-0-93-941689-9}}) * ''Feminism and Sadomasochism'' a chapter/article in ''Feminism and Sexuality: A Reader'' (1996)
(edited by [[Stevi Jackson]] and [[Sue Scott (sociologist)|Sue Scott]]) ({{ISBN|978-0-23-110708-2}}) * ''Sex Changes: The Politics of Transgenderism'' (1997) ({{ISBN|978-1-57-344072-1}}) * ''Speaking Sex to Power: The Politics of Queer Sex'' (2001) ({{ISBN|978-1-57-344132-2}}) === Fiction === * ''[[Macho Sluts|Macho Sluts: Erotic Fiction]]'' (July 1994) ({{ISBN|978-1-55-583115-8}}) * ''Doing It for Daddy: Short and Sexy Fiction about a Very Forbidden Fantasy'' (December 1994) ({{ISBN|978-1-55-583227-8}}) * ''Doc and Fluff: The Dystopian Tale of a Girl and Her Biker'' (May 2000) ({{ISBN|978-1-55-583369-5}}) * ''No Mercy: Short Stories'' (June 2000) ({{ISBN|978-1-55-583542-2}}) * ''Melting Point'' (November 2000) ({{ISBN|978-1-55-583380-0}}) ==See also== * [[Catacombs (sex club)]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.technodyke.com/features/patcalifa1.asp Pat Califia—A three-part interview] at Technodyke.com * [http://www.black-rose.com/cuiru/archive/2-1/califia.html The First Duty of a Revolutionary is to Survive], a 1995 interview published in the free quarterly San Francisco leather zine ''Cuir Underground'' * [http://www.gendercentre.org.au/resources/polare-archive/archived-articles/era-of-the-gender-crosser.htm Era of the Gender Crosser] {{BDSM}} {{Authority control}} Christi, Texas]] [[Category:LGBT writers from the United States]] [[Category:American erotica writers]] [[Category:Lambda Literary Award winners]] [[Category:Writers from San Francisco]] [[Category:Sex-positive feminists]] [[Category:LGBT Latter Day Saints]] [[Category:LGBT people from Texas]] [[Category:LGBT people from Florida]] [[Category:Male feminists]] [[Category:Lesbian BDSM]] revision.comment: /* Appropriateness */
revision.text:
'''Raciolinguistics''' examines how [[language]] is used to construct [[Race (human categorization)|race]] and how ideas of race influence language and language use.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Qt4oDQAAQBAJ&pg=PP1&dq=raciolinguistics#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Raciolinguistics: How Language Shapes Our Ideas About Race|last=Alim|first=H. Samy|last2=Rickford|first2=John R.|last3=Ball|first3=Arnetha F.|date=2016-09-30|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190625702|language=en}}</ref> Drawing from [[sociolinguistics]] and [[linguistic anthropology]], raciolinguistics focuses on race and its relation to language. A central concern of raciolinguistics is to understand the complex meanings and implications of speech coming from a racialized subject.<ref name=":0" /> The field also explores how the relationship between race and language impacts domains like [[politics]] and [[education]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.stanford.edu/2016/12/27/link-language-race-new-book/|title=Stanford experts highlight link between language and race in new book|last=University|first=Stanford|date=2016-12-27|website=Stanford News|access-date=2017-02-27}}</ref>
Although sociolinguists and linguistic anthropologists have previously studied the intersections of language, race, and culture, raciolinguistics is a relatively new focus for scholars trying to theorize race throughout language studies. [[Nelson Flores]] and [[Jonathan Rosa]] first popularized the term in their 2015 discussion of "appropriateness" in American language and education.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Flores|first=Nelson|last2=Rosa|first2=Jonathan|date=2015-06-10|title=Undoing Appropriateness: Raciolinguistic Ideologies and Language Diversity in Education|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.17763/0017-8055.85.2.149|journal=Harvard Educational Review|language=EN|volume=85|issue=2|pages=149–171|doi=10.17763/0017-8055.85.2.149}}</ref> In 2016, [[H. Samy Alim]], [[John R. Rickford]] and [[Arnetha F. Ball]] published a book compiling raciolinguistic research.<ref name=":0" /> In their work, raciolinguists incorporate [[intersectionality]] in theorizing how various identities (e.g. gender, ethnicity, nationality) within a group and/or an individual influence lived experiences of race.
== Race and language ==
=== Languaging race === ''Languaging race'' focuses on how race can be constructed or deconstructed "through the lens of language"<ref name=":0" /> Through and by language, one can take on, discard, or impose affiliations made with a certain race; such as education level, economic status, etc.
''Languaging race'' also encompasses the theory of [[Transracial (identity)|transracialization]], made popular in the United States by the case of [[Rachel Dolezal]]. However, within raciolinguistics, the emphasis of transracialization is put on how individuals both resist racial categorization and use such categorization in order to achieve racial justice, as in the case of [[Black Lives Matter]].<ref name=":0" />
=== Racing language === ''Racing language'' uses race theory to understand how sociolinguistic variation relates to social and political processes. This includes the development of [[African American Vernacular English|African American Language]] (AAL) in the United States, the generational linguistic shifts of Punjabi communities in London, and the significance of [[Pharyngealization|pharyngeal]] versus depharyngealized Hebrew in Israel.<ref name=":0" /> Association with a racial group may be related to the use of [[ethnolect]]s or [[Ethnolinguistics|ethnolinguistic]] repertoires,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Benor|first=Sarah Bunin|date=2010-04-01|title=Ethnolinguistic repertoire: Shifting the analytic focus in language and ethnicity1|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-9841.2010.00440.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Sociolinguistics|language=en|volume=14|issue=2|pages=159–183|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9841.2010.00440.x|issn=1467-9841}}</ref> influencing the language used among a racial group and/or an individual seeking to identify with the group. This area explores the historic and systematic reasons linguistic features are associated with certain racial groups.
== In education ==
=== Appropriateness === In their critique of American language education, Nelson Flores and Jonathan Rosa argued that the standardization of "appropriate" language in American schooling creates different experiences for racialized students.<ref name=":1" /> "Appropriate" language, defined by the language of the dominant culture, is a construction of raciolinguistic ideologies that uphold certain linguistic practices as normative and others as deficient. These ideologies are defined by the White listening/speaking subject in that "[[minoritized language|language-minoritized]] students [are expected] to mimic the white speaking subject while ignoring the raciolinguistic ideologies that the white listening subject uses to position them as racial Others".<ref name=":1" />
In her LangCrit framework, Alison Crump also explored Whiteness within the construction and education of a standard English and how language scholars may further address language, race, and identity in language education.<ref>Crump, Alison (2014) Introducing [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/15427587.2014.936243?journalCode=hcil20 LangCrit: Critical Language and Race Theory, Critical Inquiry in Language Studies], 11/3</ref>
==See also== * [[Decreolization]] * [[Language ideology]] * [[Linguistic profiling]] * [[Linguistic rights]] * [[Race (human categorization)|Race]] * [[Racism]] * [[Sociolinguistics]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sociolinguistics]] [[Category:Racism]] [[Category:Race and society]] [[Category:Language and race]] [[Category:Linguistic controversies]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox person | name =Richard Oehring | image = | caption = | image_size = | birth_name = Otto Hermann Richard Oehring | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1891|6|16}} | birth_place = [[Düsseldorf]], [[German empire|Germany]] | death_date = 14 May 1940 | death_place = [[Netherlands]] | party = | occupation = Economist
writer | alma_mater = | parents = | spouse = 1. [[Cläre Jung|Cläre Otto]] (1915)
2. Margarethe Kuh (1917) | predecessor = | successor = | children = Aurora Miriam "Mimi" Oehring
(b. 1918) }} '''Richard Oehring''' (16 June 1891 – 14 May 1940) was a German economist, writer and poet who became a political activist.{{cite web|title=Richard Oehring|author=Anni Rosemarie Becker|url=http://www.lit-nrw.de/dateien/pdf-Dateien/GedenktageOehring.pdf| publisher=Gesellschaft für Literatur in Nordrhein-Westfalen e.V., Münster|accessdate=26 February 2016}}{{cite web|title=... welch eine Flamme war verloht – Richard Oehring| url=http://www.dehmlow.de/index.php/de/observations/152-welch-eine-flamme-war-verloht-richard-oehring|date=10 July 2015| publisher=Raimund Dehmlow|accessdate=26 February 2016}} ==Life== Otto Hermann Richard Oehring was born in [[Düsseldorf]]. His father was a senior official with the post office. While he was growing up he attended schools successively in [[Düsseldorf]], Hamburg and [[Berlin]]. He successfully [[Abitur|completed his schooling]] in 1909 in Berlin. By this time he was a member of the circle of youthful left wing intellectuals surrounding the poet [[Henriette Hardenberg]] and her brother Hans. A period of study in [[Munich]] followed and Richard Oehring, along with his brother Fritz joined the informal so-called "Tat" (''"Deed[s]"'') group of left-leaning politically aware liberal writers and artists: fellow members included [[Oskar Maria Graf]], [[Franz Jung]] and [[Georg Schrimpf]]. Following his return to Berlin, Richard Oehring took to contributing as a business and economics journalist to the "Buchwald Börsenberichte" newspaper. From 1912 he was providing pieces for "[[Die Aktion]]", a newly launched magazine with its focus on literature and left-wing politics in which he also published some of his poetic and lyrical creations. One of these was his essay "Der Käfig" which appeared in 1913/1914. During 1913/1914 he actively promoted "[[Die Aktion]] Authors' Evenings" at the magazine, together with the likes of [[Gottfried Benn]], [[Paul Boldt]], [[Alfred Lichtenstein (writer)|Alfred Lichtenstein]] and [[Franz Pfemfert]]. His brother Fritz was an early victim of the [[First World War|war]] which broke out in July 1914. Richard Oehring took part in the war, being stationed in [[Brussels]] where he undertook medical work. Falling ill, he returned home to [[Berlin]], but was re-assessed and declared fit for military service. He was reconscripted and deserted, eventually achieving his dismissal by refusing to accept either food or wages. In March 1915 he married [[Cläre Jung|Cläre Otto]], later described by {{Interlanguage link multi|Fritz Mierau|de}} as "the soul and muse of their little [Berlin based artists' and writers'] circle"."...die Seele und die Muse des kleinen Kreises."{{cite book |author=[[:de:Fritz Mierau|Fritz Mierau]]|title= Das Verschwinden von Franz Jung|place=Hamburg|date= 1998|publisher= Nautilus |isbn=978-3894012946|page= 57}} Starting in 1915 they produced "{{Interlanguage link multi|Die freie Straße|de}}" ''(The Free Street)'', an [[Anarchism|Anarchist]]-[[Dada]]ist journal appearing at irregular intervals and of which, by the end of 1917, six editions had been produced. Other members of the production team were [[Franz Jung]], [[Otto Gross]] and [[Georg Schrimpf]]. A feature of "Die freie Straße" was that the team took turns to take responsibility for production. Richard Oehring was the producer for editions 3 and 4. Oehring's marriage to [[Cläre Jung|Cläre Otto]] ended in divorce in 1917, and by 1918 she was living with [[Franz Jung]], although it was only in 1924 that the two of them married.{{cite web |url=http://othes.univie.ac.at/13223/1/2011-02-02_0247271.pdf |title=Franz Jung als Außenseiter |work=Diplomarbeit bei Universität Wien|author=Gisela Hairer Mag.phil.|publisher=Universität Wien Bibliotheks- und Archivwesen |date=February 2011|accessdate=27 February 2016}} The affair put an end to the friendship between Richard Oehring and Franz Jung. Following the divorce Oehring traveled to [[Vienna]] to visit [[Otto Gross]]. In Vienna he met Margarethe Kuh, a sister of Gross's friend, the writer [[Anton Kuh]]: Margarethe became Oehring's second wife. Their daughter, Aurora Miriam "Mimi" Oehring, was born in Berlin{{cite web|url=http://de3.netpure.de/cgi-bin/baseportal.pl?htx=/RDehmlow/Otto_Gross_Daten&localparams=1&db=Otto_Gross_Daten&cmd=list&range=1050,30&cmd=all&Id=1550|title=Lebenslinien: Otto Gross & Zeitgenossen – Eine Chronologie: Die Datenbank versteht sich als eine – aus Briefen und anderen Dokumenten erschlossene – Chronologie nachprüfbarer Tagesereignisse, die das Leben des österreichischen Arztes und Revolutionärs Otto Gross (1877–1920) und seiner Zeitgenossinnen und -genossen illustrieren will.|date=8 August 2015|author= Raimund Dehmlow (author & publisher)|work=Other sources state that Aurora Miriam Oehring was born in Russia, but a birth location of Berlin in Germany appears to be more persuasively sourced, and is more consistent with the time lines implicit in other sources on Richard Oehring|accessdate=27 February 2016}} in March 1918.{{cite web|url=http://www.geni.com/people/Miriam-Oehring/6000000026285709181|author= Corin Alexander Nicholls Stone (compiler)|title=Miriam Oehring|publisher=Geni / My Heritage|date=10 March 2015|accessdate=27 February 2016}} Richard Oehring now took work with [[Alfons Goldschmidt]] on the Berlin-based "Räte-Zeitung" (newspaper).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cHSnrMbNzm8C&pg=PA199&lpg=PA199&dq=%22Richard+Oehring%22+%22R%C3%A4te-Zeitung%22&source=bl&ots=e5uMyJkLLe&sig=sy8oibXGA3awxmsw0C-HQ_i3a8A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjVwcSktpjLAhWMORoKHVHfDf4Q6AEIKjAB#v=onepage&q=%22Richard%20Oehring%22%20%22R%C3%A4te-Zeitung%22&f=false|title=Artists, Intellectuals and the USPD 1917–1922 |work=Literaturwissenschaftliches Jahrbuch. N.F., 32.1991 im Auftrag des Görres-Gesellschaft|author=Richard Sheppard|pages=198–199|date=1991|publisher=Duncker & Humblot, Berlin| isbn=3-428-07198-0}} During the period of acute austerity and [[German Revolution of 1918–19|turbulence on the streets]] that followed the end of the [[First World War]] Oehring also belonged, with his comrades Ernst Jacobi und Friedrich M. Minck, to the so-called "Co-operative Council for Economic Reconstruction" (''"Rätegenossenschaft für wirtschaftlichen Aufbau"''). In 1922 Oehring moved to the [[Soviet Union]]. By May 1923 he was back in [[Berlin]], possibly on account of his wife's health. That month he wrote in a letter to "Comrade" {{Interlanguage link multi|Oskar Wöhrle|de}}, then in Konstanz, describing Margarethe's illness which he believed would be cured by plenty of rest and good food. In Berlin he worked as a trade representative for the Soviet Union, also participating in the film production unit of the Soviet sponsored [[Workers International Relief|Workers' International Relief (''IAH – Internationale Arbeiter-Hilfe / Международная рабочая помощь'')]] organisation in Berlin. In 1931 he became a member of the "Arplan".Arplan = "Arbeitsgemeinschaft zum Studium der Planwirtschaft" (''"Working Study Group on Planned Economies"'') Fellow members included [[Arvid Harnack]], [[Georg Lukács]], {{Interlanguage link multi|Friedrich Lenz|de|3=Friedrich Lenz (Nationalökonom)}} and [[Karl August Wittfogel]]. The commentator {{Interlanguage link multi|Igor Cornelissen|nl}} believes that Oehring probably accompanied the "Arplan" delegation that travelled to the Soviet Union in 1932, although his name is not included in the official list of delegates. January 1933 brought [[Machtergreifung|régime change]] [[Gleichschaltung|to]] [[Nazi Germany|Germany]]. Richard Oehrling and his family left the country the same year, relocating to the [[Netherlands]] where he worked for "Exportchleb", the Soviet trade organisation in the Netherlands, and at the same time undertaking work for the [[Russian Intelligence Community|Soviet security services]]. While in the Netherlands he was in close contact with [[Ignace Reiss]], a Soviet spy who fell foul of Moscow's shifting power structures and was shot by an [[NKVD]] [[Vladimir Pravdin|assassin]] in [[Lausanne]] a few weeks after sending a letter to [[Stalin|Party general secretary Stalin]] in which he announced his "defection", and support for [[Trotsky]] (who by this time had become a high-profile opponent of the Soviet dictator). While in the Netherlands Oehring recruited {{Interlanguage link multi|Johan Huijts|nl}}, the foreign correspondent of the "[[Nieuwe Rotterdamsche Courant|Nieuwe Rotterdamsche Courant (NRC)]]" (newspaper), to work for Soviet intelligence. It is not clear whether Oehring's resignation from "Exportchleb" in 1939 was connected with the killing of [[Ignace Reiss|Reiss]]. As an Economics advisor for the [[Nieuwe Rotterdamsche Courant|NRC]], he provided the Rotterdam newspaper with Economics reports from the Soviet Union that were published in its business section. Huijts later recalled that Oehring was much troubled by his failure to obtain Soviet citizenship during the count-down to the [[Second World War]]. In May 1940 the [[Wehrmacht|German army]] [[Battle of the Netherlands|invaded the Netherlands]] and Richard Oehrling responded by committing suicide on 14 May, the day on which the Netherlands formally surrendered. During the [[Netherlands in World War II|German occupation]] Margarethe Oehrling was arrested and imprisoned, but both she and their daughter survived the war. Margarethe was still alive in 1977. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oehring, Richard}} [[Category:German-language writers]] [[Category:German opinion journalists]] [[Category:People from Düsseldorf]] [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1940 deaths]]
